lines.value: the great ape project gap founded in 1993 is an international organization of primatologists anthropologists ethicists and others who advocate a united nations declaration of the rights of great apes that would confer basic legal rights on non human great apes chimpanzees bonobos gorillas and orangutans
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rights suggested are the right to life the protection of individual liberty and the prohibition of torture
lines.name: English

lines.value: the organization also monitors individual great ape activity in the united states through a census program
lines.name: English

lines.value: once rights are established gap would demand the release of great apes from captivity currently 3100 are held in the us including 1280 in biomedical research facilities
lines.name: English

lines.value: the book of the same name edited by philosophers paola cavalieri and peter singer features contributions from thirty four authors including jane goodall and richard dawkins who have submitted articles voicing their support for the project
lines.name: English

lines.value: the authors write that human beings are intelligent animals with a varied social emotional and cognitive life
lines.name: English

lines.value: if great apes also display such attributes the authors argue they deserve the same consideration humans extend to members of their own species
lines.name: English

lines.value: the book highlights findings that support the capacity of great apes to possess rationality and self consciousness and the ability to be aware of themselves as distinct entities with a past and future
lines.name: English

lines.value: documented conversations in sign languages with individual great apes are the basis for these findings
lines.name: English

lines.value: other subjects addressed within the book include the division placed between humans and great apes great apes as persons progress in gaining rights for the severely intellectually disabled once an overlooked minority and the situation of great apes in the world today
lines.name: English

lines.value: their biological similarity with humans is also key to the traits for which they are valuable as research subjects
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example testing of monoclonal antibody treatments cannot be done in species less similar to humans than chimpanzees
lines.name: English

lines.value: because the antibodies do not elicit immune responses in chimpanzees they persist in the blood as they do in humans and their effects can be evaluated
lines.name: English

lines.value: in monkeys and other non apes the antibodies are rapidly cleared from the bloodstream
lines.name: English

lines.value: monoclonal antibody treatments are being developed for cancer autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis lupus erythematosus multiple sclerosis psoriasis and crohn's disease and asthma
lines.name: English

lines.value: chimpanzees also possess unique advantages in evaluating new hepatitis b and c vaccines and treatments for malaria again because of the similarity in their response to these antigens to humans
lines.name: English

lines.value: the great ape project is campaigning to have the united nations endorse a declaration on great apes
lines.name: English

lines.value: this would extend what the project calls the community of equals to include chimpanzees bonobos gorillas and orangutans
lines.name: English

lines.value: the declaration seeks to extend to non human great apes the protection of three basic interests the right to life the protection of individual liberty and the prohibition of torture
lines.name: English

lines.value: the declaration states that members of the community of equals which includes humans may not be killed except in certain strictly defined circumstances such as self defense
lines.name: English

lines.value: the declaration states that members of the community of equals are not to be deprived of their liberty and are entitled to immediate release where there has been no form of due process
lines.name: English

lines.value: under the proposed declaration the detention of great apes who have not been convicted of any crime or who are not criminally liable should be permitted only where it can be shown that the detention is in their own interests or is necessary to protect the public
lines.name: English

lines.value: the declaration says there must be a right of appeal either directly or through an advocate to a judicial tribunal
lines.name: English

lines.value: the declaration prohibits the torture defined as the deliberate infliction of severe pain on any great ape whether wantonly or because of a perceived benefit to others
lines.name: English

lines.value: under international human rights law this is a jus cogens principle and under all major human rights documents it cannot at any time be derogated by any state
lines.name: English

lines.value: professor colin blakemore head of the medical research council in the united kingdom from 2003 2007 is opposed to granting rights to non human apes stating i can see no current necessity for the use of great apes and i'm pleased that they're not being used and that every effort is being made to reduce the use of other primates
lines.name: English

lines.value: but i worry about the principle of where the moral boundaries lie
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is only one very secure definition that can be made and that is between our species and others blakemore suggests that it would be necessary to perform research on great apes if humans were threatened by a pandemic virus that afflicted only humans and other great apes
lines.name: English

lines.value: a study commissioned by the national institute of health nih and conducted by the institute of medicine iom concluded in a report see report brief ) released on december 15 2011 that while the chimpanzee has been a valuable animal model in past research most current use of chimpanzees for biomedical research is unnecessary
lines.name: English

lines.value: the primary recommendation is that the use of chimpanzees in research be guided by a set of principles and criteria in effect to greatly limit government funded research using chimpanzees
lines.name: English

lines.value: falling short of calling for the out right ban of using chimpanzees for research the report acknowledged that new emerging or reemerging diseases may require the use of chimpanzees echoing professor colin blakemore's concern
lines.name: English

lines.value: francis collins director of nih announced on the same day the report was released that he accepted the recommendations and will develop the implementation plan which includes the forming of an expert committee to review all submitted grant applications and projects already underway involving the use of chimpanzees
lines.name: English

lines.value: furthermore no new grant applications using chimpanzees will be reviewed until further notice
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 21 september 2012 nih announced that 110 chimpanzees owned by the government will be retired
lines.name: English

lines.value: nih owns about 500 chimpanzees for research this move signifies the first step to wind down nih's investment in chimpanzee research according to francis collins
lines.name: English

lines.value: currently housed at the new iberia research center in louisiana 10 of the retired chimpanzees will go to the chimpanzee sanctuary chimp haven while the rest will go to texas biomedical research institute in san antonio
lines.name: English

lines.value: however concerns over the chimpanzee's status in the texas biomedical research institute as research ineligible rather than retired prompted nih to reconsider the plan and it announced on 17 october 2012 that as many chimpanzees as possible will be relocated to chimp haven by august 2013 and eventually all 110 will move there
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 22 january 2013 a nih task force released a report calling for the government to retire most of the chimpanzees the us government support
lines.name: English

lines.value: the panel concluded that the animals provide little benefit in biomedical discoveries except in a few disease cases which can be supported by a small population of 50 primates for future research
lines.name: English

lines.value: other approaches such as genetically altered mice should be developed and refined

lines.value: on 13 november 2013 the us house of representatives and the us senate passed the chimpanzee health improvement maintenance and protection act approving the funding to expand the capacity of chimp haven and other chimpanzee sanctuaries thus allowing the transfer of almost all of the apes owned by the federal government to live in a more natural and group environment than in the laboratory

lines.value: due to his technical ability vision tactical intelligence and passing ability he excelled at building attacking plays and creating chances for team mates although he was also capable of scoring himself due to his powerful and accurate shot

lines.value: ferrari was born in alessandria italy and began his footballing career with local club alessandria calcio in the prima divisione nazionale in 1923 making his debut in the newly established serie a on 6 october 1929 in a 3 1 home win over roma

lines.value: he remained with the club until 1930 aside from a brief loan to internaples during the 1925 26 season

lines.value: the following year ferrari changed over to juventus fc and was handed the number 10 shirt over that five year period 1930-1935 he played in 125 games and scored 35 goals in addition to providing many assists

lines.value: although the official number of assists he provided was not recorded it was said to be extremely high

lines.value: the next move ferrari would make would be to inter in 1935 and subsequently to bologna for the 1940 41 season before returning to juventus once again for the final season of his career in which he also acted as coach retiring from football in 1942

lines.value: hu 210 is a synthetic cannabinoid that was first synthesized in 1988 from 1r,5s)-myrtenol by a group led by professor raphael mechoulam at the hebrew university

lines.value: hu 210 is 100 to 800 times more potent than natural thc from cannabis and has an extended duration of action
lines.name: English

lines.value: hu 210 is the -)-11-dimethylheptyl analog of 11-hydroxy δ 8 tetrahydrocannabinol in some references it is called 11-dimethylheptyl 11-hydroxytetrahydrocannabinol
lines.name: English

lines.value: the abbreviation hu stands for hebrew university
lines.name: English

lines.value: the + enantiomer of hu 210 has almost all of the cannabinoid activity with the − enantiomer hu 211 being inactive as a cannabinoid but instead acting as an nmda antagonist having neuroprotective effects
lines.name: English

lines.value: hu 210 promotes proliferation but not differentiation of cultured embryonic hippocampal neural stem and progenitor cells likely via a sequential activation of cb 1 receptors g i o proteins and erk signaling
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was also indicated by this increased neural growth to entail antianxiety and antidepressant effects
lines.name: English

lines.value: hu 210 alongside other synthetic cannabinoids like win 55212-2 and jwh 133 is implicated in preventing the inflammation caused by amyloid beta proteins involved in alzheimer's disease in addition to preventing cognitive impairment and loss of neuronal markers
lines.name: English

lines.value: this anti inflammatory action is induced through the activation of cannabinoid receptors which prevents microglial activation that elicits the inflammation
lines.name: English

lines.value: in addition cannabinoids completely abolish neurotoxicity related to microglia activation in rat models
lines.name: English

lines.value: hu 210 is a potent analgesic with many of the same effects as natural thc
lines.name: English

lines.value: hu 210 is the enantiomer of hu 211 dexanabinol
lines.name: English

lines.value: the original synthesis of hu 210 is based on an acid catalyzed condensation of -)-myrtenol and 11-dimethylheptylresorcinol 35-dihydroxy-1-(11-dimethylheptyl)benzol
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to the us customs and border protection hu 210 was discovered in spice gold incense products seized at the us border in january 2009
lines.name: English

lines.value: over 100 lb of spice products were seized based on this finding
lines.name: English

lines.value: hu 210 was also detected in three spice products in the uk as reported in june 2009
lines.name: English

lines.value: hu 210 is not listed in the schedules set out by the united nations single convention on narcotic drugs from 1961 nor their convention on psychotropic substances from 1971 so the signatory countries to these international drug control treaties are not required by said treaties to control hu 210

lines.value: hu 210 is banned in new zealand as of 8 may 2014

lines.value: roque gonzalez de santa cruz sj 17 november 1576 15 november 1628 was a jesuit priest who was the first missionary among the guarani people in paraguay
lines.name: English

lines.value: he is honored as a martyr and saint by the catholic church
lines.name: English

lines.value: gonzalez was born in the city of asuncion now part of paraguay on 17 november 1576
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was the son of the spanish colonists bartolome gonzalez y de villaverde and maria de santa cruz who were both from noble families
lines.name: English

lines.value: due to the large native population in the region he spoke guarani fluently from an early age as well as his native spanish
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1598 at the age of 23 gonzalez was ordained a priest by fernando trexo y senabria ofm the bishop of cordoba to serve that diocese
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1609 he became a member of the society of jesus beginning his work as a missionary in what is now brazil
lines.name: English

lines.value: he became the first european person to enter the region known today as the state of rio grande do sul extending the system of jesuit reductions begun in paraguay to that region
lines.name: English

lines.value: gonzalez arrival in the area happened only after his developing delicate relationships of trust with local indigenous leaders some of whom feared that the priests were preparing the way for the arrival of masses of spanish colonists in their land
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1613 gonzalez led the founding of the reduction of san ignacio mini
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1615 he founded itapua which is now the city of posadas in the argentine province of misiones
lines.name: English

lines.value: then he had to move the reduction to the other side of the river now the site of the city of encarnacion
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also founded the reductions of concepcion de la sierra candelaria 1619 candelaria 1627 san javier yapeyu now in the province of corrientes san nicolas asuncion del iyui and caaro now in brazil
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the region of iyui he had difficulties with the local chieftain and sorcerer cacique nezu
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 15 november 1628 while preparing to oversee the installation of a new bell for the church at the mission of todos los santos de caaro gonzalez was struck down and killed along with his fellow jesuit juan del castillo sj upon the orders of the local chieftain nhecu who opposed the missions
lines.name: English

lines.value: after their deaths their bodies were dragged into the church which was set ablaze
lines.name: English

lines.value: two days later their colleague alonso rodriguez y olmedo sj was also murdered
lines.name: English

lines.value: gonzalez was beatified by pope pius xi on 28 january 1934
lines.name: English

lines.value: he and his companions were later canonized by pope john paul ii in asuncion thus becoming the first native of that country to be declared a saint by the catholic church
lines.name: English

lines.value: gonzalez has been named the patron saint of the cities of posadas argentina and encarnacion paraguay
lines.name: English

lines.value: liturgically he is commemorated on 16 november along with the other martyrs of the rio de la plata
lines.name: English

lines.value: gonzalez heart and the weapon which killed him are in the chapel of the martyrs in his native city of asuncion

lines.value: william seward burroughs ii (; february 5 1914 - august 2 1997 was an american writer and visual artist
lines.name: English

lines.value: burroughs was a primary figure of the beat generation and a major postmodernist author whose influence is considered to have affected a range of popular culture as well as literature
lines.name: English

lines.value: burroughs wrote eighteen novels and novellas six collections of short stories and four collections of essays
lines.name: English

lines.value: five books have been published of his interviews and correspondences
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also collaborated on projects and recordings with numerous performers and musicians and made many appearances in films
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was also briefly known by the pen name william lee
lines.name: English

lines.value: burroughs created and exhibited thousands of paintings and other visual art works including his celebrated gunshot paintings
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was born into a wealthy family in st louis missouri grandson of the inventor and founder of the burroughs corporation william seward burroughs i and nephew of public relations manager ivy lee
lines.name: English

lines.value: burroughs began writing essays and journals in early adolescence but did not begin publicizing his writing until his thirties
lines.name: English

lines.value: he left home in 1932 to attend harvard university studied english and anthropology as a postgraduate and later attended medical school in vienna
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1942 burroughs enlisted in the us army to serve during world war ii but was turned down by the office of strategic services and navy after which he picked up the drug addiction that affected him for the rest of his life while working a variety of jobs
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1943 while living in new york city he befriended allen ginsberg and jack kerouac and out of their mutual influence grew the foundation of the beat generation which was later a defining influence on the 1960s counterculture
lines.name: English

lines.value: much of burroughs work is semiautobiographical primarily drawn from his experiences as a heroin addict as he lived throughout mexico city london paris and tangier in morocco as well as from his travels in the south american amazon
lines.name: English

lines.value: burroughs accidentally killed his second wife joan vollmer in 1951 in mexico city with a pistol during a drunken william tell game he was consequently convicted of manslaughter
lines.name: English

lines.value: burroughs found success with his confessional first novel junkie 1953 but he is perhaps best known for his third novel naked lunch 1959 a highly controversial work that was the subject of a court case after it was challenged as being in violation of the us sodomy laws
lines.name: English

lines.value: with brion gysin he also popularized the literary cut up technique in works such as the nova trilogy 1961-1964
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1983 burroughs was elected to the american academy and institute of arts and letters and in 1984 he was awarded the ordre des arts et des lettres by france
lines.name: English

lines.value: jack kerouac called burroughs the greatest satirical writer since jonathan swift a reputation he owes to his lifelong subversion of the moral political and economic systems of modern american society articulated in often darkly humorous sardonicism
lines.name: English

lines.value: j g ballard considered burroughs to be the most important writer to emerge since the second world war while norman mailer declared him the only american writer who may be conceivably possessed by genius
lines.name: English

lines.value: burroughs created visual art throughout his life time but never exhibited it until 1987 after the death of his friend and collaborator brion gysin
lines.name: English

lines.value: for the next and last 10 years of his life he presented his paintings and drawings at museums and galleries worldwide
lines.name: English

lines.value: burroughs had one child william s burroughs jr 1947-1981 with his second wife joan vollmer
lines.name: English

lines.value: william burroughs died at his home in lawrence kansas after suffering a heart attack in 1997

lines.value: his was a prominent family of english ancestry in st louis missouri

lines.value: his grandfather william seward burroughs i founded the burroughs adding machine company which evolved into the burroughs corporation

lines.value: melanocytes are melanin producing neural crest derived cells located in the bottom layer the stratum basale of the skin's epidermis the middle layer of the eye the uvea the inner ear vaginal epithelium meninges bones and heart

lines.value: melanin is a dark pigment primarily responsible for skin color

lines.value: once synthesized melanin is contained in special organelles called melanosomes which can be transported to nearby keratinocytes to induce pigmentation

lines.value: functionally melanin serves as protection against uv radiation

lines.value: through a process called melanogenesis melanocytes produce melanin which is a pigment found in the skin eyes hair nasal cavity and inner ear

lines.value: this melanogenesis leads to a long lasting pigmentation which is in contrast to the pigmentation that originates from oxidation of already existing melanin
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are both basal and activated levels of melanogenesis in general lighter skinned people have low basal levels of melanogenesis
lines.name: English

lines.value: exposure to uv b radiation causes increased melanogenesis
lines.name: English

lines.value: the purpose of melanogenesis is to protect the hypodermis the layer under the skin from damage by uv b radiation
lines.name: English

lines.value: the color of the melanin is black allowing it to absorb a majority of the uv b light and block it from passing through the epidermis
lines.name: English

lines.value: since the action spectrum of sunburn and melanogenesis are virtually identical they are assumed to be induced by the same mechanism

lines.value: the agreement of the action spectrum with the absorption spectrum of dna points towards the formation of cyclobutane pyrimidine dimers cpds direct dna damage

lines.value: typically between 1000 and 2000 melanocytes are found per square millimeter of skin or approximately 5% to 10% of the cells in the basal layer of epidermis

lines.value: although their size can vary melanocytes are typically 7 um in length

lines.value: the difference in skin color between lightly and darkly pigmented individuals is due not to the number quantity of melanocytes in their skin but to the melanocytes level of activity quantity and relative amounts of eumelanin and pheomelanin

lines.value: in addition cytokine production by melanocytes can be triggered by cytokines secreted by other nearby immune cells

lines.value: melanocytes are ideally positioned in the epidermis to be sentinels against harmful pathogens

lines.value: melanocytes likely work in concert with both keratinocytes and langerhans cells both of which are also actively phagocytic to contribute to the immune response

lines.value: emmanuel joseph sieyes 3 may 1748 - 20 june 1836 most commonly known as the abbe sieyes (), was a french roman catholic abbe clergyman and political writer
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was one of the chief political theorists of the french revolution and also played a prominent role in the french consulate and first french empire
lines.name: English

lines.value: his 1789 pamphlet what is the third estate
lines.name: English

lines.value: became the manifesto of the revolution helping to transform the estates general into the national assembly in june 1789
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was offered a position on the french directory but turned it down
lines.name: English

lines.value: after becoming a director in 1799 he was among the instigators of the coup d'etat of 18 brumaire 9 november which brought napoleon bonaparte to power
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also coined the term sociologie in an unpublished manuscript and made significant theoretical contributions to the nascent social sciences
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes was born on 3 may 1748 as the fifth child of honore and annabelle sieyes in the town of frejus in southern france
lines.name: English

lines.value: his father was a local tax collector who made a humble income and while the family had some noble blood they were commoners
lines.name: English

lines.value: his earliest education came by way of tutors and of the jesuits
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also spent some time at the college of the doctrinaires of draguignan
lines.name: English

lines.value: he originally wanted to join the military and become a soldier but his frail health combined with his parents piety led him instead to pursue a religious career
lines.name: English

lines.value: the vicar general of frejus offered aid to sieyes because he felt he was obliged to his father
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes spent ten years at the seminary of saint sulpice in paris
lines.name: English

lines.value: there he studied theology and engineering to prepare himself to enter the priesthood
lines.name: English

lines.value: he quickly gained a reputation at the school for his aptitude and interest in the sciences combined with his obsession over the new philosophic principles and dislike for conventional theology
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes was educated for priesthood in the catholic church at the sorbonne
lines.name: English

lines.value: while there he became influenced by the teachings of john locke condillac quesnay mirabeau turgot the encyclopedistes and other enlightenment political thinkers all in preference to theology
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1770 he obtained his first theology diploma ranking at the bottom of the list of passing candidates - a reflection of his antipathy toward his religious education
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1772 he was ordained as a priest and two years later he obtained his theology license
lines.name: English

lines.value: despite sieyes embrace of enlightenment thinking he was ordained to the priesthood in 1773
lines.name: English

lines.value: in spite of this he was not hired immediately
lines.name: English

lines.value: he spent this time researching philosophy and developing music until about a year later in october 1774 when as the result of demands by powerful friends he was promised a canonry in brittany
lines.name: English

lines.value: unfortunately for sieyes this canonry went into effect only when the preceding holder died
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the end of 1775 sieyes acquired his first real position as secretary to the bishop of treguier where he spent two years as deputy of the diocese
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is here that he sat in the estates of brittany and became disgusted with the immense power the privileged classes held
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1780 the bishop of treguier was transferred to the bishopric of chartres and sieyes accompanied him there as his vicar general eventually becoming a canon of the cathedral and chancellor of the diocese of chartres
lines.name: English

lines.value: due to the fact that the bishop of treguier had high regards for sieyes he was able to act as a representative of his diocese in the upper chamber of the clergy
lines.name: English

lines.value: . it was during this time that sieyes became aware of the ease with which nobles advanced in ecclesiastical offices compared to commoners
lines.name: English

lines.value: in particular he was resentful of the privileges granted to the nobles within the church system and thought the patronage system was a humiliation for commoners
lines.name: English

lines.value: while remaining in ecclesiastical offices sieyes maintained a religious cynicism at odds with his position
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the time he took his orders to enter priesthood sieyes had freed himself from all superstitious sentiments and ideas even when corresponding with his deeply religious father sieyes showed a severe lack of piety for the man in charge of the diocese of chartres
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is theorised that sieyes accepted a religious career not because he had any sort of strong religious inclination but because he considered it the only means to advance his career as a political writer
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1788 louis xvi of france proposed the convocation of the estates general of france after an interval of more than a century and a half
lines.name: English

lines.value: this proposal and jacques necker's invitation to french writers to state their views as to the organization of society by estates enabled sieyes to publish his celebrated january 1789 pamphlet qu'est ce que le tiers-etat
lines.name: English

lines.value: what is the third estate he begins his answer :"what is the third estate
lines.name: English

lines.value: everything
lines.name: English

lines.value: what has it been hitherto in the political order
lines.name: English

lines.value: nothing
lines.name: English

lines.value: what does it desire to be
lines.name: English

lines.value: something this phrase which was to remain famous is said to have been inspired by nicolas chamfort
lines.name: English

lines.value: the pamphlet was very successful and its author despite his clerical vocation which made him part of the first estate was elected as the last the twentieth of the deputies to the third estate from paris to the estates general
lines.name: English

lines.value: he played his main role in the opening years of the revolution drafting the declaration of the rights of man and of the citizen expanding on the theories of national sovereignty popular sovereignty and representation implied in his pamphlet with a distinction between active and passive citizens that justified suffrage limited to male owners of property
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes's pamphlet incited a radical reaction from its audience because it involved the political issues of the day and twisted them in a more revolutionary direction
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the third chapter of the pamphlet sieyes proposed that the third estate wanted to be something
lines.name: English

lines.value: but he also stated that in allowing the privileged orders to exist they are asking to become the least thing possible
lines.name: English

lines.value: the usage of such rhetoric in his pamphlet appealed to common causes to unite the audience
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the same time it influenced them to move beyond simple demands and take a more radical position on the nature of government
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this case the radical position taken by the third estate created a sense of awareness that the problems of france were not simply a matter of addressing royal tyranny but that unequal privileges under the law had divided the nation
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was from this point that the revolution's struggle for fair distribution of power and equal rights began in earnest
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes's pamphlet played a key role in shaping the currents of revolutionary thought that propelled france towards the french revolution
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his pamphlet he outlined the desires and frustrations of the alienated class of people that made up the third estate
lines.name: English

lines.value: he attacked the foundations of the french ancien regime by arguing the nobility to be a fraudulent institution preying on an overburdened and despondent bourgeoisie
lines.name: English

lines.value: the pamphlet voiced concerns that were to become crucial matters of debate during the convocation of the estates general of 1789
lines.name: English

lines.value: whereas the aristocracy defined themselves as an elite ruling class charged with maintaining the social order in france sieyes saw the third estate as the primary mechanism of public service
lines.name: English

lines.value: expression of radical thought at its best the pamphlet placed sovereignty not in the hands of aristocrats but instead defined the nation of france by its productive orders composed of those who would generate services and produce goods for the benefit of the entire society
lines.name: English

lines.value: these included not only those involved in agricultural labor and craftsmanship but also merchants brokers lawyers financiers and others providing services
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes challenged the hierarchical order of society by redefining who represented the nation
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his pamphlet he condemns the privileged orders by saying their members were enjoying the best products of society without contributing to their production
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes essentially argued that the aristocracy's privileges established it as an alien body acting outside of the nation of france and deemed noble privilege treason to the commonwealth
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes's pamphlet had a significant influence on the structural concerns that arose surrounding the convocation of the estates general
lines.name: English

lines.value: specifically the third estate demanded that the number of deputies for their order be equal to that of the two privileged orders combined and most controversially that the states general vote not by orders but by heads
lines.name: English

lines.value: the pamphlet took these issues to the masses and their partial appeasement was met with revolutionary reaction
lines.name: English

lines.value: by addressing the issues of representation directly sieyes inspired resentment and agitation that united the third estate against the feudalistic traditions of the ancien regime
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a result the third estate demanded the reorganization of the estates general but the two other orders proved unable or unwilling to provide a solution
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes proposed that the members of the first and second order join the third estate and become a united body to represent the nation as a whole
lines.name: English

lines.value: he not only suggested an invitation however but also stated that the third estate had the right to consider those who denied this invitation to be in default of their national responsibility
lines.name: English

lines.value: the third estate adopted this measure on 5 june 1789 by doing so they assumed the authority to represent the nation
lines.name: English

lines.value: this radical action was confirmed when they decided to change the name of the estates general to the national assembly indicating that the separation of orders no longer existed
lines.name: English

lines.value: although not noted as a public speaker he spoke rarely and briefly sieyes held major political influence and he recommended the decision of the estates to reunite its chamber as the national assembly although he opposed the abolition of tithes and the confiscation of church lands
lines.name: English

lines.value: his opposition to the abolition of tithes discredited him in the national assembly and he was never able to regain his authority
lines.name: English

lines.value: elected to the special committee on the constitution he opposed the right of absolute veto for the king of france which honore mirabeau unsuccessfully supported
lines.name: English

lines.value: he had considerable influence on the framing of the departmental system but after the spring of 1790 he was eclipsed by other politicians and was elected only once to the post of fortnightly president of the constituent assembly
lines.name: English

lines.value: like all other members of the constituent assembly he was excluded from the legislative assembly by the ordinance initially proposed by maximilien robespierre that decreed that none of its members should be eligible for the next legislature
lines.name: English

lines.value: he reappeared in the third national assembly known as the national convention of the french republic september 1792 - september 1795
lines.name: English

lines.value: he voted for the death of louis xvi but not in the contemptuous terms sometimes ascribed to him
lines.name: English

lines.value: he participated to the constitution committee that drafted the girondin constitutional project
lines.name: English

lines.value: menaced by the reign of terror and offended by its character sieyes even abjured his faith at the time of the installation of the cult of reason afterwards when asked what he had done during the terror he famously replied j'ai vecu i lived
lines.name: English

lines.value: ultimately sieyes failed to establish the kind of bourgeois revolution he had hoped for one of representative order devoted to the peaceful pursuit of material comfort his initial purpose was to instigate change in a more passive way and to establish a constitutional monarchy
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to william sewell sieyes pamphlet set the tone and direction of the french revolution...but its author could hardly control the revolution's course over the long run
lines.name: English

lines.value: even after 1791 when the monarchy seemed to many to be doomed sieyes continued to assert his belief in the monarchy which indicated he did not intend for the revolution to take the course it did
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the period he served in the national assembly sieyes wanted to establish a constitution that would guarantee the rights of french men and would uphold equality under the law as the social goal of the revolution he was ultimately unable to accomplish his goal
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the execution of robespierre in 1794 sieyes reemerged as an important political player during the constitutional debates that followed
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1795 he went on a diplomatic mission to the hague and was instrumental in drawing up a treaty between the french and batavian republics
lines.name: English

lines.value: he resented the constitution of the year iii enacted by the directory and refused to serve as a director of the republic
lines.name: English

lines.value: in may 1798 he went as the plenipotentiary of france to the court of berlin in order to try to induce prussia to ally with france against the second coalition this effort ultimately failed
lines.name: English

lines.value: his prestige grew nonetheless and he was made director of france in place of jean francois rewbell in may 1799
lines.name: English

lines.value: nevertheless sieyes considered ways to overthrow the directory and is said to have taken in view the replacement of the government with unlikely rulers such as archduke charles of austria and karl wilhelm ferdinand of brunswick a major enemy of the revolution
lines.name: English

lines.value: he attempted to undermine the constitution and thus caused the revived jacobin club to be closed while making offers to general joubert for a coup d'etat
lines.name: English

lines.value: the death of joubert at the battle of novi and the return of napoleon bonaparte from the egypt campaign put an end to this project but sieyes regained influence by reaching a new understanding with bonaparte
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the coup of 18 brumaire sieyes and his allies dissolved the directory allowing napoleon to seize power
lines.name: English

lines.value: thereafter sieyes produced the constitution which he had long been planning only to have it completely remodeled by bonaparte who thereby achieved a coup within a coup - bonaparte's constitution of the year viii became the basis of the french consulate of 1799 1804
lines.name: English

lines.value: corps legislatif appointed bonaparte sieyes and roger ducos as consuls of the french republic
lines.name: English

lines.value: in order to once again begin the function of government these three men took the oath of inviolable fidelity to the sovereignty of the people to the french republic one and indivisible to equality liberty and the representative system although sieyes had many ideas a lot of them were disfavored by bonaparte and roger ducos
lines.name: English

lines.value: one aspect that was agreed upon was the structure of power
lines.name: English

lines.value: a list of active citizens formed the basis of the proposed political structure
lines.name: English

lines.value: this list was to choose one tenth of its members to form a communal list eligible for local office from the communal list one tenth of its members were to form a departmental list finally one further list was made up from one tenth of the members of the departmental list to create the national list
lines.name: English

lines.value: this national list is where the highest officials of the land were to be chosen
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes envisioned a tribunat and a college des conservateurs to act as the shell of the national government
lines.name: English

lines.value: the tribunat would present laws and discuss ratification of these laws in front of a jury
lines.name: English

lines.value: this jury would not have any say in terms of what the laws granted consist of rather whether or not these laws passed
lines.name: English

lines.value: the college des conservateurs would be renewed from the national list
lines.name: English

lines.value: the main responsibility of the college des conservateurs was to choose the members of the two legislative bodies and protect the constitution by right of absorption
lines.name: English

lines.value: by this curious provision the college could forcibly elect to its ranks any individual deemed dangerous to the safety of the state who would then be disqualified from any other office
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was a way to keep a closer eye on anyone who threatened the state
lines.name: English

lines.value: the power of the college des conservateurs was extended to electing the titular head of government the grand electeur
lines.name: English

lines.value: the grand electeur would hold office for life but have no power
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the grand electeur threatened to become dangerous the college des conservateurs would absorb him
lines.name: English

lines.value: the central idea of sieyes plan was a division of power
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes soon retired from the post of provisional consul which he had accepted after 18 brumaire and became one of the first members of the senat conservateur acting as its president in 1799 this concession was attributed to the large estate at crosne that he received from napoleon
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the plot of the rue saint nicaise in late december 1800 sieyes defended the arbitrary and illegal proceedings whereby napoleon rid himself of the leading jacobins
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the era of the first empire 1804-1814 sieyes rarely emerged from his retirement
lines.name: English

lines.value: when napoleon briefly returned to power in 1815 sieyes was named to the chamber of peers
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1816 after the second restoration sieyes was expelled from the academy of moral and political sciences by louis xviii
lines.name: English

lines.value: he then moved to brussels but returned to france after the july revolution of 1830
lines.name: English

lines.value: he died in paris in 1836 at the age of 88
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1795 sieyes became one of the first members of what would become the academy of moral and political sciences of the institute of france
lines.name: English

lines.value: when the academie francaise was reorganized in 1803 he was elected in the second class replacing in chair 31 jean sylvain bailly who had been guillotined on 12 november 1793 during the reign of terror
lines.name: English

lines.value: however after the second restoration in 1815 sieyes was expelled for his role in the execution of king louis xvi and was replaced by the marquis of lally tollendal who was named to the academy by a royal decree
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1780 sieyes coined the term sociologie in an unpublished manuscript
lines.name: English

lines.value: the term was used again fifty years later by the philosopher auguste comte to refer to the science of society which is known in english as sociology
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes was always considered intellectual and intelligent by his peers and mentors alike
lines.name: English

lines.value: through the virtue of his own thoughts he progressed in his ideologies from personal experiences
lines.name: English

lines.value: starting at a young age he began to feel repulsion towards the privileges of the nobility
lines.name: English

lines.value: he deemed this advantage gained by noble right as unfair to those of the lower class
lines.name: English

lines.value: this distaste he felt for the privileged class became evident during his time at the estates of brittany where he was able to observe with dissatisfaction domination by the nobility
lines.name: English

lines.value: aside from his opinions towards nobility sieyes also had a passion for music
lines.name: English

lines.value: he devoted himself assiduously to cultivating music as he had plenty of spare time
lines.name: English

lines.value: along with cultivating music sieyes also enjoyed writing reflections concerning these pieces
lines.name: English

lines.value: sieyes had a collection of musical pieces he called la catologue de ma petite musique although sieyes was passionate about his ideologies he had a rather uninvolved social life
lines.name: English

lines.value: his journals and papers held much information about his studies but almost nothing pertaining to his personal life
lines.name: English

lines.value: his associates referred to him as cold and vain
lines.name: English

lines.value: in particular charles maurice de talleyrand perigord remarked that men are in his eyes chess pieces to be moved they occupy his mind but say nothing to his heart
lines.name: English

lines.value: * emmanuel joseph sieyes what is the third estate
lines.name: English

lines.value: sir charles villiers stanford 30 september 1852 - 29 march 1924 was an irish composer music teacher and conductor
lines.name: English

lines.value: born to a well off and highly musical family in dublin stanford was educated at the university of cambridge before studying music in leipzig and berlin
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was instrumental in raising the status of the cambridge university musical society attracting international stars to perform with it.while still an undergraduate stanford was appointed organist of trinity college cambridge
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1882 aged 29 he was one of the founding professors of the royal college of music where he taught composition for the rest of his life
lines.name: English

lines.value: from 1887 he was also professor of music at cambridge
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a teacher stanford was sceptical about modernism and based his instruction chiefly on classical principles as exemplified in the music of brahms
lines.name: English

lines.value: among his pupils were rising composers whose fame went on to surpass his own such as gustav holst and ralph vaughan williams
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a conductor stanford held posts with the bach choir and the leeds triennial music festival
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford composed a substantial number of concert works including seven symphonies but his best remembered pieces are his choral works for church performance chiefly composed in the anglican tradition
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was a dedicated composer of opera but none of his nine completed operas has endured in the general repertory
lines.name: English

lines.value: some critics regarded stanford together with hubert parry and alexander mackenzie as responsible for a renaissance in music from the british isles
lines.name: English

lines.value: however after his conspicuous success as a composer in the last two decades of the 19th century his music was eclipsed in the 20th century by that of edward elgar as well as former pupils
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford was born in dublin the only son of john james stanford and his second wife mary nee henn
lines.name: English

lines.value: john stanford was a prominent dublin lawyer examiner to the court of chancery in ireland and clerk of the crown for county meath
lines.name: English

lines.value: his wife was the third daughter of william henn master of the high court of chancery in ireland and granddaughter of the judge william henn
lines.name: English

lines.value: both parents were accomplished amateur musicians john stanford was a cellist and a noted bass singer who was chosen to perform the title role in mendelssohn's elijah at the irish premiere in 1847
lines.name: English

lines.value: mary stanford was an amateur pianist capable of playing the solo parts in concertos at dublin concerts
lines.name: English

lines.value: the young stanford was given a conventional education at a private day school in dublin run by henry tilney bassett who concentrated on the classics to the exclusion of other subjects
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford's parents encouraged the boy's precocious musical talent employing a succession of teachers in violin piano organ and composition
lines.name: English

lines.value: three of his teachers were former pupils of ignaz moscheles including his godmother elizabeth meeke of whom stanford recalled she taught me before i was twelve years old to read at sight
lines.name: English

lines.value: she made me play every day at the end of my lesson a mazurka of chopin never letting me stop for a mistake
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the time i had played through the whole fifty two mazurkas i could read most music of the calibre my fingers could tackle with comparative ease one of the young stanford's earliest compositions a march in d major written when he was eight years old was performed in the pantomime at the theatre royal dublin three years later
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the age of seven stanford gave a piano recital for an invited audience playing works by beethoven handel mendelssohn moscheles mozart and bach
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of his songs was taken up by the university of dublin choral society and was well received
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1860s dublin received occasional visits from international stars and stanford was able to hear famous performers such as joseph joachim henri vieuxtemps and adelina patti
lines.name: English

lines.value: the annual visit of the italian opera company from london led by giulia grisi giovanni matteo mario and later therese tietjens gave stanford a taste for opera that remained with him all his life
lines.name: English

lines.value: when he was ten his parents took him to london for the summer where he stayed with his mother's uncle in mayfair
lines.name: English

lines.value: while there he took composition lessons from the composer and teacher arthur o'leary and piano lessons from ernst pauer professor of piano at the royal academy of music ram
lines.name: English

lines.value: on his return to dublin his godmother having left ireland he took lessons from henrietta flynn another former leipzig conservatory pupil of moscheles and later from robert stewart organist of st patrick's cathedral as well as from a third moscheles pupil michael quarry
lines.name: English

lines.value: during his second spell in london two years later he met the composer arthur sullivan and the musical administrator and writer george grove who later played important parts in his career
lines.name: English

lines.value: john stanford hoped that his son would follow him into the legal profession but accepted his decision to pursue music as a career
lines.name: English

lines.value: however he stipulated that stanford should have a conventional university education before going on to musical studies abroad
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford tried unsuccessfully for a classics scholarship at trinity hall cambridge but gained an organ scholarship and later a classics scholarship at queens college
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the time he went up to cambridge in 1870 he had written a substantial number of compositions including vocal music both sacred and secular and orchestral works a rondo for cello and orchestra and a concert overture
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford immersed himself in the musical life of the university to the detriment of his latin and greek studies
lines.name: English

lines.value: he composed religious and secular vocal works a piano concerto and incidental music for longfellow's play a spanish student
lines.name: English

lines.value: in november 1870 he appeared as piano soloist with the cambridge university musical society cums and quickly became its assistant conductor and a committee member
lines.name: English

lines.value: the society had declined in excellence since its foundation in 1843
lines.name: English

lines.value: its choir consisted solely of men and boys the lack of women singers severely limited the works that the society could present
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford was unable to persuade the members to admit women and so he staged what the musical times called a bloodless revolution in february 1872 he co founded a mixed choir the amateur vocal guild whose performances immediately put those of the cums singers in the shade
lines.name: English

lines.value: the members of cums rapidly changed their minds and agreed to a merger of the two choirs with women given associate membership of the society
lines.name: English

lines.value: the conductor of the combined choir was john larkin hopkins who was also organist of trinity college
lines.name: English

lines.value: he became ill and handed over the conductorship to stanford in 1873
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford was also appointed hopkins's deputy organist at trinity and moved from queens to trinity in april 1873
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the summer of that year stanford made his first trip to continental europe
lines.name: English

lines.value: he went to bonn for the schumann festival held there where he met joachim and brahms
lines.name: English

lines.value: his growing love of the music of schumann and brahms marked him as a classicist at a time when many music lovers were divided into the classical or the modernist camps the latter represented by the music of liszt and wagner
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford was not constrained by the fashion for belonging to one camp or the other he immensely admired die meistersinger though he was unenthusiastic about some of wagner's other works
lines.name: English

lines.value: after leaving bonn he returned home by way of switzerland and then paris where he saw meyerbeer's le prophete
lines.name: English

lines.value: hopkins's illness proved fatal and after his death the trinity authorities invited stanford to take over as organist of the college
lines.name: English

lines.value: he accepted with the proviso that he was to be released each year for a spell of musical study in germany
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fellows of the college resolved on 21 february 1874 two days after his appointment stanford took the final examinations for his classics degree
lines.name: English

lines.value: he ranked 65th of 66 and was awarded a third class degree
lines.name: English

lines.value: on the recommendation of sir william sterndale bennett former professor of music at cambridge and now director of the royal academy of music stanford went to leipzig in the summer of 1874 for lessons with carl reinecke professor of composition and piano at the leipzig conservatory
lines.name: English

lines.value: the composer thomas dunhill commented that by 1874 it was the tail end of the leipzig ascendancy when the great traditions of mendelssohn had already begunto fade nevertheless stanford did not seriously consider studying anywhere else
lines.name: English

lines.value: neither dublin nor london offered any comparable musical training the most prestigious british music school the royal academy of music ram was at that time hidebound and reactionary
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was dismayed to find in leipzig that bennett had recommended him to a german pedant no more progressive than the teachers at the ram
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford said of reinecke of all the dry musicians i have ever known he was the most desiccated
lines.name: English

lines.value: he had not a good word for any contemporary composer he loathed wagner sneered at brahms and had no enthusiasm of any sort stanford's biographer paul rodmell suggests that reinecke's ultra conservatism may have been unexpectedly good for his pupil as it may have encouraged stanford to kick against the traces during his time in leipzig stanford took piano lessons from robert papperitz 1826-1903 organist of the city's nikolaikirche whom he found more helpful
lines.name: English

lines.value: among stanford's compositions in 1874 was a setting of part one of longfellow's poem the golden legend
lines.name: English

lines.value: he intended to set the entire poem but gave up defeated by longfellow's numerous but unconnected characters stanford ignored this and other early works when assigning opus numbers in his mature years
lines.name: English

lines.value: the earliest compositions in his official list of works are a four movement suite for piano and a toccata for piano which both date from 1875
lines.name: English

lines.value: after a second spell in leipzig with reinecke in 1875 which was no more productive than the first stanford was recommended by joachim to study in berlin the following year with friedrich kiel whom stanford found a master at once sympathetic and able i learnt more from him in three months than from all the others in three years
lines.name: English

lines.value: returning to cambridge in the intervals of his studies in germany stanford had resumed his work as conductor of cums
lines.name: English

lines.value: he found the society in good shape under his deputy eaton faning and able to tackle demanding new works
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1876 the society presented one of the first performances in britain of the brahms requiem
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1877 cums came to national attention when it presented the first british performance of brahms's first symphony
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the same period stanford was becoming known as a composer
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was composing prolifically though he later withdrew some of his works from these years including a violin concerto which according to rodmell suffered from undistinguished thematic material in 1875 his first symphony won the second prize in a competition held at the alexandra palace for symphonies by british composers although he had to wait a further two years to hear the work performed
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the same year stanford directed the first performance of his oratorio the resurrection given by cums
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the request of alfred tennyson he wrote incidental music for tennyson's drama queen mary performed at the lyceum theatre london in april 1876
lines.name: English

lines.value: in april 1878 despite the disapproval of his father stanford married jane anna maria wetton known as jennie a singer whom he had met when she was studying in leipzig
lines.name: English

lines.value: she was the daughter of henry champion wetton of joldwynds in surrey who had died in 1870
lines.name: English

lines.value: they had a daughter geraldine mary born in 1883 and a son guy desmond born in 1885
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1878 and 1879 stanford worked on his first opera the veiled prophet to a libretto by his friend william barclay squire
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was based on a poem by thomas moore with characters including a virgin priestess and a mystic prophet and a plot that culminates in poisoning and stabbing
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford offered the work to the opera impresario carl rosa who refused it and suggested that the composer should try to have it staged in germany its success will unfortunately have much greater chances here if accepted abroad referring to the enormous popularity of sullivan's comic operas rosa added if the work was of the pinafore style it would be quite another matter stanford had greatly enjoyed sullivan's cox and box but the veiled prophet was intended to be a serious work of high drama and romance
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford had made many useful contacts during his months in germany and his friend the conductor ernst frank got the piece staged at the konigliches schauspiel in hanover in 1881
lines.name: English

lines.value: reviewing the premiere for the musical times stanford's friend j a fuller maitland wrote mr stanford's style of instrumentation is built more or less on that of schumann while his style of dramatic treatment bears more resemblance to meyerbeer than to that of any other master other reviews were mixed and the opera had to wait until 1893 for its english premiere
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford nevertheless continued to seek operatic success throughout his career
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his lifelong enthusiasm for opera he differed strikingly from his contemporary hubert parry who made one attempt at composing opera and then renounced the genre
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the early 1880s stanford was becoming a major figure in the british musical scene
lines.name: English

lines.value: his only major rivals were seen as sullivan frederic hymen cowen parry alexander mackenzie and arthur goring thomas
lines.name: English

lines.value: sullivan was by this time viewed with suspicion in high minded musical circles for composing comic rather than grand operas cowen was regarded more as a conductor than as a composer and the other three though seen as promising had not so far made a clear mark as stanford had done
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford helped parry in particular to gain recognition commissioning incidental music from him for a cambridge production of aristophanes the birds and a symphony the cambridge for the musical society
lines.name: English

lines.value: at cambridge stanford continued to raise the profile of cums as well as his own by securing appearances by leading international musicians including joachim hans richter alfredo piatti and edward dannreuther
lines.name: English

lines.value: the society attracted further attention by premiering works by cowen parry mackenzie goring thomas and others
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford was also making an impression in his capacity as organist of trinity raising musical standards and composing what his biographer jeremy dibble calls some highly distinctive church music including a service in b 1879 the anthem the lord is my shepherd 1886 and the motet justorum animae 1888
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the first half of the 1880s stanford collaborated with the author gilbert a beckett on two operas savonarola and the canterbury pilgrims
lines.name: English

lines.value: the former was well received at its premiere in hamburg in april 1884 but received a critical savaging when staged at covent garden in july of the same year
lines.name: English

lines.value: parry commented privately it seems very badly constructed for the stage poorly conceived and the music though clean and well managed is not striking or dramatic the most severe public criticism was in the theatre whose reviewer wrote the book of savonarola is dull stilted and from a dramatic point of view weak
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is not however so crushingly tiresome as the music fitted to it
lines.name: English

lines.value: savonarola has gone far to convince me that opera is quite out of [stanford's] line and that the sooner he abandons the stage for the cathedral the better for his musical reputation the canterbury pilgrims had been premiered in london in april 1884 three months before savonarola was presented at covent garden
lines.name: English

lines.value: it had a better reception than the latter though reviews pointed out stanford's debt to die meistersinger and complained of a lack of emotion in the love music
lines.name: English

lines.value: george grove agreed with the critics writing to parry charlie's music contains everything but sentiment
lines.name: English

lines.value: love not at all - that i heard not a grain of
lines.name: English

lines.value: and i do think that there might be more tune
lines.name: English

lines.value: melody is not a thing to be avoided surely in 1896 a critic wrote that the opera had just such a book as would have suited the late alfred cellier
lines.name: English

lines.value: he would probably have made of it a charming light english opera
lines.name: English

lines.value: but dr stanford has chosen to use it for the exemplification of those advanced theories which we know him to hold and he has given us music which would incline us to think that die meistersinger had been his model
lines.name: English

lines.value: the effect of the combination is not happy
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1883 the royal college of music was set up to replace the short lived and unsuccessful national training school for music ntsm
lines.name: English

lines.value: neither the ntsm nor the longer established royal academy of music had provided adequate musical training for professional orchestral players and the founder director of the college george grove was determined that the new institution should succeed in doing so
lines.name: English

lines.value: his two principal allies in this undertaking were the violinist henry holmes and stanford
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a study of the founding of the college david wright notes that stanford had two main reasons for supporting grove's aim
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first was his belief that a capable college orchestra was essential to give students of composition the chance to experience the sound of their music
lines.name: English

lines.value: his second reason was the severe contrast between the competence of german orchestras and the performance of their british counterparts
lines.name: English

lines.value: he accepted grove's offer of the posts of professor of composition and with holmes conductor of the college orchestra
lines.name: English

lines.value: he held the professorship for the rest of his life among the best known of his many pupils were samuel coleridge taylor gustav holst ralph vaughan williams john ireland frank bridge and arthur bliss
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford was never an easy going teacher
lines.name: English

lines.value: he insisted on one to one tutorials and worked his pupils hard
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of them herbert howells recalled corner any stanford pupil you like and ask him to confess the sins he most hated being discovered in by his master
lines.name: English

lines.value: he will tell you slovenliness and vulgarity when these went into the teacher's room they came out badly damaged
lines.name: English

lines.value: against compromise with dubious material or workmanship stanford stubbornly set his face another pupil edgar bainton recalled to stanford's regret many of his pupils who achieved eminence as composers broke away from his classical brahmsian precepts as he had himself rebelled against reinecke's conservatism
lines.name: English

lines.value: the composer george dyson wrote in a certain sense the very rebellion he fought was the most obvious fruit of his methods
lines.name: English

lines.value: and in view of what some of these rebels have since achieved one is tempted to wonder whether there is really anything better a teacher can do for his pupils than drive them into various forms of revolution the works of some of stanford's pupils including holst and vaughan williams entered the general repertory in britain and to some extent elsewhere as stanford's never did
lines.name: English

lines.value: for many years after his death it seemed that stanford's greatest fame would be as a teacher
lines.name: English

lines.value: among his achievements at the rcm was the establishment of an opera class with at least one operatic production every year
lines.name: English

lines.value: from 1885 to 1915 there were 32 productions all of them conducted by stanford
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1887 stanford was appointed professor of music at cambridge in succession to sir george macfarren who died in october of that year
lines.name: English

lines.value: up to this time the university had awarded music degrees to candidates who had not been undergraduates at cambridge all that was required was to pass the university's music examinations
lines.name: English

lines.value: stanford was determined to end the practice and after six years he persuaded the university authorities to agree
lines.name: English

lines.value: three years study at the university became a prerequisite for sitting the bachelor of music examinations
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the last decades of the 19th century stanford's academic duties did not prevent him from composing or performing
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was appointed conductor of the bach choir london in 1885 succeeding its founding conductor otto goldschmidt
lines.name: English

lines.value: he held the post until 1902
lines.name: English

lines.value: hans von bulow conducted the german premiere of stanford's irish symphony in hamburg in january 1888 and was sufficiently impressed by the work to programme it in berlin shortly afterwards
lines.name: English

lines.value: richter conducted it in vienna and mahler later conducted it in new york
lines.name: English

lines.value: for the theatre royal cambridge stanford composed incidental music for productions of aeschylus's the eumenides 1885 and sophocles oedipus tyrannos 1887
lines.name: English

lines.value: the times said of the former mr stanford's music is dramatically significant as well as beautiful in itself
lines.name: English

lines.value: it has moreover that quality so rare among modern composers - style in both sets of music stanford made extensive use of leitmotifs in the manner of wagner the critic of the times noted the wagnerian character of the prelude to oedipus
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1890s bernard shaw writing as music critic of the world voiced mixed feelings about stanford
lines.name: English

lines.value: in shaw's view the best of stanford's works displayed an uninhibited irish character
lines.name: English

lines.value: the critic was dismissive of the composer's solemn victorian choral music
lines.name: English

lines.value: in july 1891 shaw's column was full of praise for stanford's capacity for spirited tunes declaring that richard d'oyly carte should engage him to succeed sullivan as the composer of savoy operas

lines.name: English

lines.value: it was there that he and dana scott wrote the paper finite automata and their decision problems
lines.name: English

lines.value: soon using nondeterministic automata they were able to reprove kleene's result that finite state machines exactly accept regular languages
lines.name: English

lines.value: as to the origins of what was to become computational complexity theory the next summer rabin returned to the lamb estate
lines.name: English

lines.value: john mccarthy posed a puzzle to him about spies guards and passwords which rabin studied and soon after he wrote an article degree of difficulty of computing a function and hierarchy of recursive sets nondeterministic machines have become a key concept in computational complexity theory particularly with the description of the complexity classes p and np
lines.name: English

lines.value: rabin then returned to jerusalem researching logic and working on the foundations of what would later be known as computer science
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was an associate professor and the head of the institute of mathematics at the hebrew university at 29 years old and a full professor by 33
lines.name: English

lines.value: rabin recalls there was absolutely no appreciation of the work on the issues of computing
lines.name: English

lines.value: mathematicians did not recognize the emerging new field
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1960 he was invited by edward f moore to work at bell labs where rabin introduced probabilistic automata that employ coin tosses in order to decide which state transitions to take
lines.name: English

lines.value: he showed examples of regular languages that required a very large number of states but for which you get an exponential reduction of the number of states if you go over to probabilistic automata
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1969 rabin proved that the second order theory of n successors is decidable
lines.name: English

lines.value: a key component of the proof implicitly showed determinacy of parity games which lie in the third level of the borel hierarchy
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1975 rabin finished his tenure as rector of the hebrew university of jerusalem and went to the massachusetts institute of technology in the usa as a visiting professor
lines.name: English

lines.value: gary miller was also there and had his polynomial time test for primality based on the extended riemann hypothesis
lines.name: English

lines.value: while there rabin invented the miller rabin primality test a randomized algorithm that can determine very quickly but with a tiny probability of error whether a number is prime
lines.name: English

lines.value: rabin's method was based on previous work of gary miller that solved the problem deterministically with the assumption that the generalized riemann hypothesis is true but rabin's version of the test made no such assumption
lines.name: English

lines.value: fast primality testing is key in the successful implementation of most public key cryptography and in 2003 miller rabin robert m solovay and volker strassen were given the paris kanellakis award for their work on primality testing
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1976 he was invited by joseph traub to meet at carnegie mellon university and presented the primality test
lines.name: English

lines.value: after he gave that lecture traub had said no no this is revolutionary and it's going to become very important in 1979 rabin invented the rabin cryptosystem the first asymmetric cryptosystem whose security was proved equivalent to the intractability of integer factorization
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1981 rabin reinvented a weak variant of the technique of oblivious transfer invented by wiesner under the name of multiplexing allowing a sender to transmit a message to a receiver where the receiver has some probability between 0 and 1 of learning the message with the sender being unaware whether the receiver was able to do so.in 1987 rabin together with richard karp created one of the most well known efficient string search algorithms the rabin karp string search algorithm known for its rolling hash
lines.name: English

lines.value: rabin's more recent research has concentrated on computer security
lines.name: English

lines.value: he is currently the thomas j watson sr professor of computer science at harvard university and professor of computer science at hebrew university
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the spring semester of 2007 he was a visiting professor at columbia university teaching introduction to cryptography
lines.name: English

lines.value: rabin is a foreign member of the united states national academy of sciences a member of the french academy of sciences and a foreign member of the royal society
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was also the phd advisor of saharon shelah a researcher in mathematical logic
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1976 the turing award was awarded jointly to rabin and dana scott for a paper written in 1959 the citation for which states that the award was granted for their joint paper finite automata and their decision problems which introduced the idea of nondeterministic machines which has proved to be an enormously valuable concept
lines.name: English

lines.value: their scott & rabin classic paper has been a continuous source of inspiration for subsequent work in this field in 1995 rabin was awarded the israel prize in computer sciences
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2010 rabin was awarded the tel aviv university dan david prize future category jointly with leonard kleinrock and gordon e moore for computers and telecommunications
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2017 rabin was awarded an honorary doctor of science from harvard university
