lines.value: a midshipman is an officer of the junior most rank in the royal navy united states navy and many commonwealth navies
lines.name: English

lines.value: commonwealth countries which use the rank include canada naval cadet australia bangladesh namibia new zealand south africa india pakistan singapore sri lanka and kenya
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 17th century a midshipman was a rating for an experienced seaman and the word derives from the area aboard a ship amidships either where the original rating worked on the ship or where he was berthed
lines.name: English

lines.value: beginning in the 18th century a commissioned officer candidate was rated as a midshipman and the seaman rating began to slowly die out
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the napoleonic era 1793-1815 a midshipman was an apprentice officer who had previously served at least three years as a volunteer officer's servant or able seaman and was roughly equivalent to a present day petty officer in rank and responsibilities
lines.name: English

lines.value: after serving at least three years as a midshipman or master's mate he was eligible to take the examination for lieutenant
lines.name: English

lines.value: promotion to lieutenant was not automatic and many midshipmen took positions as master's mates for an increase in pay and responsibility aboard ship
lines.name: English

lines.value: midshipmen in the united states navy were trained and served similarly to midshipman in the royal navy although unlike their counterparts in the royal navy a midshipman was a warrant officer rank until 1912
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the 19th century changes in the training of naval officers in both the royal navy and the united states navy led to the replacement of apprenticeship aboard ships with formal schooling in a naval college
lines.name: English

lines.value: midshipman began to mean an officer cadet at a naval college
lines.name: English

lines.value: trainees now spent around four years in a college and two years at sea prior to promotion to commissioned officer rank
lines.name: English

lines.value: between the mid 19th and mid 20th centuries time at sea declined to less than a year as the entry age was increased from 12 to 18.ranks equivalent to midshipman exist in many other navies
lines.name: English

lines.value: using us midshipman or pre fleet board uk midshipman as the basis for comparison the equivalent rank would be a naval cadet in training to become a junior commissioned officer
lines.name: English

lines.value: using post fleet board uk midshipman for comparison the rank would be the most junior commissioned officer in the rank structure and similar to a us ensign in role and responsibility
lines.name: English

lines.value: in many romance languages the literal translation of the local term for midshipman into english is navy guard including the french garde marine spanish guardia marina portuguese guarda marinha and italian guardiamarina
lines.name: English

lines.value: today these ranks all refer to naval cadets but historically they were selected by the monarchy and were trained mostly on land as soldiers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rank of midshipman originated during the tudor and stuart eras and originally referred to a post for an experienced seaman promoted from the ordinary deck hands who worked in between the main and mizzen masts and had more responsibility than an ordinary seaman but was not a military officer or an officer in training
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first published use of the term midshipman was in 1662
lines.name: English

lines.value: the word derives from an area aboard a ship amidships but it refers either to the location where midshipmen worked on the ship or the location where midshipmen were berthed
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the 18th century four types of midshipman existed midshipman original rating midshipman extraordinary midshipman apprentice officer and midshipman ordinary
lines.name: English

lines.value: some midshipmen were older men and while most were officer candidates who failed to pass the lieutenant examination or were passed over for promotion some members of the original rating served as late as 1822 alongside apprentice officers without themselves aspiring to a commission
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1794 all midshipmen were considered officer candidates and the original rating was phased out
lines.name: English

lines.value: beginning in 1661 boys who aspired to become officers were sent by their families to serve on ships with a letter of service from the crown and were paid at the same rate as midshipmen
lines.name: English

lines.value: the letter instructed the admirals and captains that the bearer was to be shown such kindness as you shall judge fit for a gentleman both in accommodating him in your ship and in furthering his improvement
lines.name: English

lines.value: their official rating was volunteer per order but they were often known as king's letter boys to distinguish their higher social class from the original midshipman rating
lines.name: English

lines.value: beginning in 1677 royal navy regulations for promotion to lieutenant required service as a midshipman and promotion to midshipman required some time at sea
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the napoleonic era the regulations required at least three years of services as a midshipman or master's mate and six years of total sea time
lines.name: English

lines.value: sea time was earned in various ways most boys served this period at sea in any lower rating either as a servant of one of the ship's officers a volunteer or a seaman
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the 1730s the rating volunteer per order was phased out and replaced with a system where prospective midshipmen served as servants for officers
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example a captain was allowed four servants for every 100 men aboard his ship many of these servants were young men destined to become officers
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1729 the royal naval academy in portsmouth - renamed the royal naval college in 1806 - was founded for 40 students aged between 13 and 16 who would take three years to complete a course of study defined in an illustrated book and would earn two years of sea time as part of their studies
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rating of midshipman by order or midshipman ordinary was used specifically for graduates of the royal naval college to distinguish them from midshipmen who had served aboard ship who were paid more
lines.name: English

lines.value: the school was unpopular in the navy because officers enjoyed the privilege of having servants and preferred the traditional method of training officers via apprenticeship
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1794 officers servants were abolished and a new class of volunteers called volunteer class i was created for boys between the ages of 11 and 13 who were considered future midshipmen and lived in the gunroom on a ship of the line or with the midshipmen on a frigate or smaller vessel
lines.name: English

lines.value: volunteers were paid £6 per year
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1816 the rating of midshipman ordinary was phased out and all apprentice officers were rated as midshipmen
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 18th century royal navy rank and position on board ship was defined by a mix of two hierarchies an official hierarchy of ranks and a conventionally recognized social divide between gentlemen and non gentlemen
lines.name: English

lines.value: boys aspiring for a commission were often called young gentlemen instead of their substantive rating to distinguish their higher social standing from the ordinary sailors
lines.name: English

lines.value: generally aboard most warships common seamen berthed in the fo'c'sle while officers were quartered at the stern
lines.name: English

lines.value: occasionally a midshipman would be posted aboard a ship in a lower rating such as able seaman but would eat and sleep with his social equals in the cockpit
lines.name: English

lines.value: approximately 50 percent of midshipmen were the sons of professional men which included the sons of naval officers and there were notable sailing families throughout the age of sail such as the saumarez hood and parker families
lines.name: English

lines.value: the niceties of preferment and promotion made family connections an obvious advantage for prospective officers
lines.name: English

lines.value: members of the peerage and landed gentry formed the next largest group about 27 percent of officers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the numbers were smaller but similarly their connections gave them excellent prospects for promotion and they had a considerable influence on the royal navy
lines.name: English

lines.value: a notable member of this group was prince william later william iv who served as a midshipman from 1780 1785
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rest were from commercial or working class backgrounds and because of the advantages possessed by the nobility and professional sailors their chances of promotion to lieutenant were slim
lines.name: English

lines.value: since most midshipmen were from the gentry or had family connections with sailing ships many used their connections to have their names placed on a ship's books
lines.name: English

lines.value: the practice known colloquially as false muster was common even though it was technically illegal and frowned upon
lines.name: English

lines.value: this allowed some boys to be promoted to midshipmen or in some cases lieutenant without having completed the required amount of time at sea
lines.name: English

lines.value: a notable example was thomas cochrane whose uncle had him entered at the age of five his name was carried on various ships until he was 18 and received his commission
lines.name: English

lines.value: when uniforms were introduced in the navy in 1748 midshipmen started wearing the same uniform as commissioned officers
lines.name: English

lines.value: they also began wearing their traditional badge of rank a white patch of cloth with a gold button and a twist of white cord on each side of the coat collar
lines.name: English

lines.value: the uniform emphasized that midshipmen were gentlemen and officers under instruction
lines.name: English

lines.value: midshipmen were expected to work on the ship but were also expected to learn navigation and seamanship
lines.name: English

lines.value: they were expected to have learned already as able seamen and volunteers to rig sails other duties included keeping watch relaying messages between decks supervising gun batteries commanding small boats and taking command of a sub division of the ship's company under the supervision of one of the lieutenants
lines.name: English

lines.value: on smaller ships midshipmen were instructed by a senior master's mate often a passed midshipman who taught them mathematics navigation and sailing lore
lines.name: English

lines.value: larger ships would carry a schoolmaster who was rated as a midshipman but usually was a civilian like the chaplain
lines.name: English

lines.value: midshipmen were expected to keep detailed navigational logs which were shown to the captain to assess their progress
lines.name: English

lines.value: prior to promotion to lieutenant a commissioned officer candidate in the royal navy had to pass a formal examination
lines.name: English

lines.value: officially a prospective lieutenant was at least 19 and was expected to produce proof of his service which would include certificates from his commanders and journals kept while a midshipman
lines.name: English

lines.value: however most midshipmen aspired to take the lieutenant examination at age 17 or 18 and the typical age of a midshipman was between 15 and 22
lines.name: English

lines.value: the candidate was summoned before a board of three captains and questioned about seamanship navigation and discipline
lines.name: English

lines.value: the board would ask questions such as an enemy is observed give orders for clearing your ship and make all the necessary preparations for engaging
lines.name: English

lines.value: like the board which might be an ad hoc affair the actual exam questions were not standardized and their content depended mostly on individual captains
lines.name: English

lines.value: in seamanship the candidate was expected to be able to splice ropes reef a sail work a ship in sailing and shift his tides
lines.name: English

lines.value: in navigation he was expected to be able to keep a reckoning of the ship's way by plane sailing to use mercator projection maps and observation of the sun and stars to determine the course and position of the ship and to understand the variation of the compass
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was also expected to be qualified to do the duty of an able seaman and midshipman
lines.name: English

lines.value: failure usually meant six more months of sea service before the examination could again be attempted
lines.name: English

lines.value: some men never passed it
lines.name: English

lines.value: successful completion made the midshipman a passed midshipman
lines.name: English

lines.value: from the 18th century until the second half of the 19th century a midshipman in the royal navy who passed the lieutenant's examination did not automatically receive a commission
lines.name: English

lines.value: midshipmen with political connections were promoted first while others would wait their turn on a roster
lines.name: English

lines.value: during wartime when large numbers of ships and men might be lost in battle most passed midshipman would be promoted in a year or two but during peacetime the wait might be so long that the midshipman would eventually be considered too old and lose his chance for a commission
lines.name: English

lines.value: passed midshipmen awaiting promotion often elected to become master's mates a high ranking petty officer who assisted the master with his duties served on watch as deputy to the lieutenants and commanded small boats
lines.name: English

lines.value: a midshipman who became master's mate earned an increase in pay from £2 5s to £3 16s per month but initially reduced his chances at a commission because master's mates along with masters were assumed to have a working class background
lines.name: English

lines.value: over time however appointment to master's mate became considered a normal part of the path to a commission the situation caused some confusion during the last part of the 18th century when two parallel roles - master's mates trying to become masters and former midshipmen working toward a commission - held the same title and responsibilities aboard ship
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the first years of the 19th century the term mate without the prefix master's was used for passed midshipmen to distinguish them from master's mates who had not served as midshipmen
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1824 the rating of master's assistant replaced master's mate and mate continued to be used unofficially by passed midshipmen
lines.name: English

lines.value: these changes helped eliminate the confusion caused by the mingling of midshipmen in the navigator's branch
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1838 a royal commission presided over by the duke of wellington recommended the institution of the rank of mate as an official step between midshipman and lieutenant
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1861 mate was abolished in favor of sub lieutenant
lines.name: English

lines.value: when congress created the united states navy in 1794 midshipman was listed as a rank of warrant officer in the naval act of 1794 and they were appointed by the president of the united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: midshipmen had similar duties and responsibilities as in the royal navy and were typically young men between the age of 14 and 22 in training to become a naval officer
lines.name: English

lines.value: passed midshipman was first used in 1819 and was an official rank of the us navy
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the long period of peace between 1815 and 1846 midshipmen had few opportunities for promotion and their warrants were often obtained via patronage
lines.name: English

lines.value: the poor quality of officer training in the us navy became visible after the somers affair an alleged mutiny aboard the training ship uss somers in 1842 and the subsequent execution of midshipman philip spencer
lines.name: English

lines.value: spencer had gained his post aboard the somers via the influence of his father united states secretary of war john c spencer
lines.name: English

lines.value: the original royal naval college closed in 1837 after which the only method for training midshipmen in the royal navy was aboard ships
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1844 the rank of naval cadet was created and to qualify as a midshipman a candidate had to be 14 years old successfully pass an admiralty examination and have two years of service as a naval cadet or three years of service in the navy
lines.name: English

lines.value: a decline in qualified officers prompted the navy to order training in a ship at anchor for all cadets which began in 1857 aboard hms illustrious which was replaced by hms britannia in 1859
lines.name: English

lines.value: britannia was moved to portland in 1862 and to the present location of the britannia royal naval college dartmouth in 1863
lines.name: English

lines.value: beginning in the 1840s the normal entry age for executive officer cadets those destined to command ships and fleets was between 12 and 13 and instruction consisted of two years of classroom training during which time trainees were rated as naval cadets
lines.name: English

lines.value: cadets who received a first class passing grade in studies seamanship and conduct on their final examination could receive a credit for up to a year of sea time and could be rated as midshipmen immediately after passing out of the college
lines.name: English

lines.value: after passing out of the college cadets served aboard a special training vessel for one year
lines.name: English

lines.value: cadets were then rated as midshipmen and served aboard the fleet another two years
lines.name: English

lines.value: midshipmen lived in the gunroom kept watches and ran the ship's boats
lines.name: English

lines.value: they received instruction in navigation every day
lines.name: English

lines.value: after five total years of training and having reached the age of 19 the midshipmen were eligible to take the examination for lieutenant
lines.name: English

lines.value: after passing the examination for lieutenant midshipmen were commissioned as sub lieutenants and were transferred to the royal naval college greenwich which opened in 1873 as the university of the navy
lines.name: English

lines.value: beginning in 1903 officer training of military and engineering students was reformed by the selborne fisher scheme and engineering and executive officer candidates began to enter the navy in the same way which was termed common entry
lines.name: English

lines.value: previously engineer cadets had been trained separately at the royal naval engineering college keyham which was closed in 1910
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1903 a new preparatory college was opened at the royal naval college osborne in part of queen victoria's favorite residence but not a favorite of her successor edward vii who had donated it to the nation in 1902
lines.name: English

lines.value: training initially consisted of two years at osborne and two years at dartmouth as cadets later four years at dartmouth followed by approximately 3 years of sea duty as midshipmen prior to promotion to sub lieutenant
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1905 a new building was completed on shore to replace britannia which was named britannia royal naval college
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1913 increasing demand for officers led to recruitment of 18-year-old graduates of public schools which was called special entry and was conducted separately from selborne scheme cadets
lines.name: English

lines.value: special entry cadets trained for approximately 6 months prior to service in the fleet as midshipmen
lines.name: English

lines.value: when world war i began in 1914 all the cadets at dartmouth were quickly mobilized as midshipmen in the reserve fleet
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the war two midshipmen george drewry and wilfred malleson were awarded the victoria cross the highest award of the british commonwealth for gallantry during the landing at cape helles
lines.name: English

lines.value: after world war i ended opposition to the selborne fisher scheme led to resegregating executive and engineering officers into separate branches while common entry and special entry were maintained
lines.name: English

lines.value: after world war ii another series of reforms influenced by the quality of officers produced by the special entry scheme and other nations experience with training officer candidates in a university setting were initiated to increase the quality of officers in the navy
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1949 the entry age was increased to 16 and by 1955 the entry age was increased to 18 and entry required a minimum of two a levels
lines.name: English

lines.value: after 1957 midshipmen no longer served in the fleet
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1972 all cadets became midshipmen when the rank of cadet was abolished
lines.name: English

lines.value: congress formally authorized the establishment of the united states military academy in 1802 but it took almost 50 years to approve a similar school for naval officers
lines.name: English

lines.value: one major reason for the delay was that navy leaders preferred the apprenticeship system citing famous officers such as nelson and the captains of the war of 1812 who did not attend a formal naval school
lines.name: English

lines.value: however after the somers affair officers realized that the system for training officers had to change to be more efficient
lines.name: English

lines.value: george bancroft appointed secretary of the navy in 1845 decided to work outside of congressional approval and create a new academy for officers
lines.name: English

lines.value: he formed a council led by commodore perry to create a new system for training officers and turned the old fort severn at annapolis into a new institution which would be designated as the united states naval academy in 1851
lines.name: English

lines.value: midshipmen studied at the academy for four years and trained aboard ships each summer
lines.name: English

lines.value: midshipman began to mean passed midshipman at this time and a student at the naval academy was a cadet midshipman
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rank of ensign was created in 1862 and passed midshipmen were promoted to ensign when vacancies occurred
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1865 the department of steam enginery was created and cadet engineers were admitted to the academy for the first time
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1874 congress changed the curriculum to include four years of classroom training and two years of sea duty aboard a regular vessel prior to examinations as warranted midshipmen
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1882 congress eliminated the distinction in training between engineer and naval cadets and designated the student officers as naval cadets the name reverted to midshipmen in 1902
lines.name: English

lines.value: by an act of congress passed in 1903 two appointments as midshipmen were allowed for each senator representative and delegate in congress two for the district of columbia and five each year at large
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1912 congress authorized commissioning midshipmen as ensigns on graduation day and ended the previously required two years of post graduation sea service as warrant officers
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1930 the naval academy received accreditation as an approved technological institution
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1933 a new law enabled the naval military and coast guard academies to award bachelor of science degrees and the class of 1933 was the first to receive this degree and have it written in the diploma
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1937 the superintendent of the naval academy was granted the authority to award bachelor of science degrees to all living graduates
lines.name: English

lines.value: as dominions of the british empire formed their own navies during the 20th century further countries began using the rank of midshipman
lines.name: English

lines.value: today australia new zealand south africa pakistan india singapore sri lanka bangladesh and kenya use the rank
lines.name: English

lines.value: prior to 1968 canada also used the rank of midshipman until the national defence act consolidated the royal canadian navy with the army and air force into a single military called the canadian forces
lines.name: English

lines.value: as part of the act the rank of midshipman was replaced with the rank of naval cadet
lines.name: English

lines.value: in royal navy slang a midshipman is sometimes referred to as a snotty
lines.name: English

lines.value: two popular stories give origins for the term the first claims that it arose from a shortage of handkerchiefs among midshipmen who would consequently use their sleeves to wipe their noses
lines.name: English

lines.value: prince william later william iv is sometimes cited as a notorious example of this practice among midshipmen
lines.name: English

lines.value: the other story claims that the three buttons formerly sewn onto midshipmen's jacket cuffs were placed there to prevent them from wiping their noses on their sleeves
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the modern royal navy a midshipman is the lowest rank of officer and ranks with second lieutenant in the british army and pilot officer in the royal air force and above all enlisted and warrant ranks
lines.name: English

lines.value: a midshipman's rank insignia which has changed little since napoleonic times is called a turnback a white patch of cloth with a gold button and a twist of white cord on each side of the coat collar
lines.name: English

lines.value: prospective officers must have at least five gcses including english and maths plus at least 180 ucas points from a levels or other suitable qualifications each qualification must be over 45 ucas points
lines.name: English

lines.value: they must pass a two and a half day assessment called the admiralty interview board and a medical examination
lines.name: English

lines.value: as of 2013 it is no longer the case that those joining the navy as university graduates start as sub lieutenants with non graduates joining as midshipmen
lines.name: English

lines.value: graduates and non graduates all start as midshipmen and wait to be promoted at the same time
lines.name: English

lines.value: general basic training initial officer training for royal navy officers takes place at the britannia royal naval college
lines.name: English

lines.value: training takes up to a year depending on specialisation all midshipmen participate in at least the first two terms which are 14 weeks each
lines.name: English

lines.value: until they have completed initial fleet training both midshipmen and sub lieutenants at britannia royal naval college do not use their substantive ranks but instead use the rank of officer cadet
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the first seven weeks of training officer cadets learn militarization and sea sense focusing on learning about the military environment along with team and leadership skills
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the second seven weeks officer cadets learn essential sea officer skills including navigation and the marine environment strategic studies and basic sea survival
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the second term officer cadets spend 10 weeks in initial fleet time serving aboard capital warships as junior ratings
lines.name: English

lines.value: upon completion of initial fleet time officer cadets return to dartmouth for four weeks to complete their final leadership assessment the maritime leadership exercise marl and a week spent with different areas of the royal navy
lines.name: English

lines.value: if they have been successful officers of all branches then pass out of the college
lines.name: English

lines.value: upon completion of initial officer training university cadet entrants engineering logistics and flight specialization officer cadets move to their second phase of training elsewhere within the royal navy
lines.name: English

lines.value: midshipmen specializing in warfare remain at the college for the initial warfare officer's foundation course which completes part of a foundation degree in naval studies equating to two thirds of a bachelor's degree on completion of initial professional training
lines.name: English

lines.value: officers can complete degrees via distance learning with the open university although completion is not required
lines.name: English

lines.value: a midshipman in the royal australian navy ran holds a commission which is effective from the date of their appointment
lines.name: English

lines.value: officer candidates enter the ran at various ranks depending on previous experience or degree qualifications graduates from a three year course non degree qualified entrants and sailor changeovers below the rank of leading seaman enter as midshipman
lines.name: English

lines.value: the french rank of garde de la marine was established in 1670 when an office of the monarchy selected young gentlemen from the nobility to serve the king in the gardes de la marine

lines.value: by restricting the french officer corps to members of the nobility there were not enough gardes to man all of the ships during wartime

lines.value: to fill the gaps volunteers were temporarily recruited from the merchant service they were allowed to hold permanent rank in the navy starting in 1763

lines.value: these professional officers wore blue uniforms to distinguish them from the gardes de la marine who wore red uniforms

lines.value: after the revolution the royal connotations of the term garde marine led to its replacement with aspirant officer cadet and later eleves de la marine naval officer candidate

lines.value: kampong cham (,, port of the chams ) is a province khaet of cambodia located on the central lowlands of the mekong river

lines.value: it borders the provinces of kampong chhnang to the west kampong thom and kratie to the north tbong khmum to the east and prey veng and kandal to the south

lines.value: all land west of the mekong remained kampong cham while land east of the river became tbong khmum province

lines.value: prior to this division kampong cham extended eastward to the international border with vietnam was the 11th largest province in cambodia and had a population of 1680694 ranked as the second most populated province in the nation

lines.value: the japanese saw or is a type of saw used in woodworking and japanese carpentry that cuts on the pull stroke unlike most european saws that cut on the push stroke
lines.name: English

lines.value: japanese saws are the best known pull saws but they are also used in turkey iran iraq and nepal
lines.name: English

lines.value: among european saws both coping saws for woodworking and jeweler's saws for metal working also cut on the pull stroke like japanese saws
lines.name: English

lines.value: cutting on the pull stroke is claimed to cut more efficiently and leave a narrower cut width ().
lines.name: English

lines.value: on the other hand a pull stroke does not easily permit putting one's body weight behind a stroke
lines.name: English

lines.value: this can be readily solved by using a vise or clamping
lines.name: English

lines.value: another disadvantage due to the arrangement and form of the teeth is that japanese saws do not work as well on hardwoods as european saws do
lines.name: English

lines.value: japanese saws were originally intended for comparatively soft woods like cypress and pine whereas european saws were intended for hard woods like oak and maple
lines.name: English

lines.value: the popularity of japanese saws in other regions of the world has resulted in the manufacture and production of a number of japanese saws outside of japan
lines.name: English

lines.value: the hmong mien also known as miao yao languages are a highly tonal language family of southern china and northern southeast asia
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are spoken in mountainous areas of southern china including guizhou hunan yunnan sichuan guangxi and hubei provinces where its speakers have been relegated to being hill people whereas the han chinese have settled the more fertile river valleys
lines.name: English

lines.value: within the last 300 400 years the hmong and some mien people have migrated to thailand laos vietnam and burma
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a result of the indochina wars many left southeast asia for australia the united states french guiana and other countries
lines.name: English

lines.value: thousands of hmong in the united states live in stockton sacramento and fresno california
lines.name: English

lines.value: hmong miao and mien yao are closely related but clearly distinct
lines.name: English

lines.value: for internal classifications see hmongic languages and mienic languages
lines.name: English

lines.value: the largest differences are due to divergent developments in the phonology
lines.name: English

lines.value: the hmongic languages appear to have kept the large set of initial consonants featured in the protolanguage but greatly reduced the distinctions in the syllable finals in particular eliminating all medial glides and final consonants
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mienic languages on the other hand have largely preserved syllable finals but reduced the number of initial consonants
lines.name: English

lines.value: early linguistic classifications placed the hmong mien languages in the sino tibetan family where they remain in many chinese classifications but the current consensus among western linguists is that they constitute a family of their own
lines.name: English

lines.value: the family is believed to have had its origins in central southern china
lines.name: English

lines.value: the current area of greatest agreement is that the languages appeared in the region between the yangtze and mekong rivers but there is reason to believe that speakers migrated there from further north with the expansion of the han chinese
lines.name: English

lines.value: the time of proto hmong mien has been estimated to be about 2500 bp 500 bc by sagart blench and sanchez mazas using traditional methods employing many lines of evidence and about 4243 bp by the automated similarity judgment program asjp an experimental algorithm for automatic generation of phonologically based phylogenies
lines.name: English

lines.value: paul k benedict an american scholar extended the austric theory to include the hmong mien languages
lines.name: English

lines.value: the hypothesis never received much acceptance for hmong mien however
lines.name: English

lines.value: kosaka 2002 argued specifically for a miao dai family
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mandarin names for these languages are miao and yao
lines.name: English

lines.value: in vietnamese the name for hmong is h'mong and the name mien is dao i.e yao although miền is also used
lines.name: English

lines.value: meo hmu mong hmao and hmong are local names for miao but since most laotian refugees in the united states call themselves hmong/mong this name has become better known in english than the others in recent decades
lines.name: English

lines.value: however except for some scholars who prefer the word the term hmong/ mong is only used within certain hmong/miao language speaking communities in china where the majority of the miao speakers live
lines.name: English

lines.value: in chinese despite the fact that it was once a derogatory term the word miao chinese 苗 the tone varies according to the dialect of chinese is now commonly used by members of all nationalities to refer to the language and the ethnolinguistic group
lines.name: English

lines.value: the chinese name yao on the other hand is for the yao nationality which is a cultural rather than ethnolinguistic group
lines.name: English

lines.value: it includes peoples speaking mien tai kadai yi and miao languages the latter called bunu rather than miao when spoken by yao
lines.name: English

lines.value: for this reason the ethnonym mien may be preferred as less ambiguous
lines.name: English

lines.value: like many languages in southern china the hmong mien languages tend to be monosyllabic and syntactically analytic
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are some of the most highly tonal languages in the world longmo and zongdi hmong have as many as twelve distinct tones
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are notable phonologically for the occurrence of voiceless sonorants and uvular consonants otherwise their phonology is quite typical of the region
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are svo in word order but are not as rigidly right branching as the tai kadai languages or most mon khmer languages since they have genitives and numerals before the noun like chinese
lines.name: English

lines.value: they are extremely poor in adpositions serial verb constructions replace most functions of adpositions in languages like english
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example a construction translating as be near would be used where in english prepositions like in or at would be used
lines.name: English

lines.value: besides their tonality and lack of adpositions another striking feature is the abundance of numeral classifiers and their use where other languages use definite articles or demonstratives to modify nouns
lines.name: English

lines.value: various unclassified sinitic languages are spoken by ethnic miao and yao
lines.name: English

lines.value: these languages have variously been proposed as having hmong mien substrata or as mixed languages including languages such as shehua laba lingling maojia badong yao various lowland yao languages 平地瑶话 including yeheni shaozhou tuhua and various pinghua dialects
lines.name: English

lines.value: sanqiao and possibly also baishi miao 拜师苗 both spoken in guizhou are mixed languages of hmongic and kam sui origins

lines.value: the programme chaired by joseph cooper took the form of a quiz with a panel of three music loving celebrities but without scoring or any winner

lines.value: each week there would be a special guest who would also have to answer questions - with the focus being on topics that related to the guest's life and career so as to lead to amusing anecdotes

lines.value: the questions to the panel were asked in a series of rounds each with a theme such as the face the music where the panel would have to identify a composer from their picture as well as the composer of the music played along with it.the most demanding round was the dummy keyboard where cooper would play a famous piece on a dummy soundless instrument requiring the panel to identify it from hand movements alone

lines.value: for the benefit of the audience at home the music in question - which cooper was hearing through earphones for the purpose of synchronisation - would be slowly faded in as the piece progressed

lines.value: another round was hidden melody where cooper would perform a popular tune in the style of a famous composer while including extracts of works by that composer to help the listeners

lines.value: christian olsson born 25 january 1980 in gothenburg is a former swedish athlete competing in high jump and triple jump
lines.name: English

lines.value: he won an olympic gold medal one gold and one silver medal in the world championships and two gold medals in the european championships as well as a further two golds in the world indoor championships
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also won the overall iaaf golden league jackpot in 2004 where he cashed in 500000 us dollars after splitting the million dollar pot with tonique williams darling
lines.name: English

lines.value: from 2007 to his retirement in 2012 he was beset by injuries which left him largely on the sidelines and unable to compete at top level competitions

lines.value: olsson had his international breakthrough in 2001 when he won silver at the 2001 world championships in athletics
lines.name: English

lines.value: he has the swedish national record outdoors 17.79 m 2004 summer olympics and the swedish national record indoors 17.83 m 2004
lines.name: English

lines.value: olsson has won the swedish championships seven times and has also competed successfully on national level in high jumping
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 7 march 2004 at the 2004 world indoor championships in athletics he jumped 17.83 m and matched the world record
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 23 august 2004 at the 2004 summer olympics he jumped 17.79 m broke the national record and won the gold medal
lines.name: English

lines.value: four of his six jumps were longer than the silver medalist's best jump
lines.name: English

lines.value: with the olympic gold he completed a rare international sweep having the olympic world indoor outdoor regional european indoor and outdoor titles
lines.name: English

lines.value: olsson first became interested in triple jump after watching jonathan edwards set the world record at the world championships in his hometown gothenburg
lines.name: English

lines.value: since 1999 olsson has been trained by yannick tregaro
lines.name: English

lines.value: before that olsson was trained by viljo nousiainen
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the autumn and winter 2004/2005 he injured his foot an injury originating from the 2004 olympic final preventing him from being able to do triple jumping at full speed
lines.name: English

lines.value: unfortunately the injury has healed very slowly and it was still in january 2006 hampering him
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his first competition after the injury in june 2006 he jumped 17.09 and seem to be back into shape
lines.name: English

lines.value: a month later he won the gold medal at european championships in his hometown gothenburg with a jump of 17.67 m at the beginning of the 2007 indoor season olsson was injured yet again and was unable to compete at the european indoor championships
lines.name: English

lines.value: olsson returned to competition in june at the iaaf golden league event in oslo jumping 17.33 m in july he won golden league event in paris with 17.56 m at the golden league event in rome he retired after the second round due to a cramp
lines.name: English

lines.value: olsson went to the 2007 world championships in athletics but had to pull out before the competition due to an injury during training

lines.value: after almost one year of rehabilitation he returned to competition in july 2008 at the annual event in stockholm dn galan but had to pull out due to injury

lines.value: afterwards he announced that he will not compete anymore during the 2008 season as such he will not participate at the beijing olympics

lines.value: the nasa m2-f1 was a lightweight unpowered prototype aircraft developed to flight test the wingless lifting body concept
lines.name: English

lines.value: its unusual appearance earned it the nickname flying bathtub and was designated the m2-f1 the m referring to manned and f referring to flight version
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1962 nasa dryden management approved a program to build a lightweight unpowered lifting body prototype
lines.name: English

lines.value: it featured a plywood shell placed over a tubular steel frame crafted at dryden
lines.name: English

lines.value: construction was completed in 1963
lines.name: English

lines.value: the lifting body concept originated in the mid 1950s at the national advisory committee for aeronautics ames aeronautical laboratory mountain view california
lines.name: English

lines.value: by february 1962 a series of possible shapes had been developed and r dale reed was working to gain support for a research vehicle
lines.name: English

lines.value: the construction of the m2-f1 was a joint effort by dryden and a local glider manufacturer the briegleb glider company
lines.name: English

lines.value: the budget was us$30000
lines.name: English

lines.value: nasa craftsmen and engineers built the tubular steel interior frame
lines.name: English

lines.value: its mahogany plywood shell was handmade by gus briegleb and company
lines.name: English

lines.value: ernie lowder a nasa craftsman who had worked on howard hughes h 4 hercules spruce goose was assigned to help briegleb
lines.name: English

lines.value: final assembly of the remaining components including aluminum tail surfaces pushrod controls and landing gear from a cessna 150 later replaced by cessna 180 landing gear ) was done at the nasa facility
lines.name: English

lines.value: the wingless lifting body aircraft design was initially conceived as a means of landing a spacecraft horizontally after atmospheric reentry
lines.name: English

lines.value: the absence of wings would make the extreme heat of reentry less damaging to the vehicle
lines.name: English

lines.value: rather than using a ballistic reentry trajectory like a command module very limited in manoeuvering range a lifting body vehicle had a landing footprint of the size of california
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first flight tests of the m2-f1 were at rogers dry lake at the end of a tow rope attached to a 1963 pontiac bonneville convertible
lines.name: English

lines.value: on april 5 1963 test pilot milt thompson lifted the m2-f1's nose off the ground for the first time on tow
lines.name: English

lines.value: speed was 86 mph
lines.name: English

lines.value: the little craft seemed to bounce uncontrollably back and forth on the main landing gear and stopped when he lowered the nose to the ground
lines.name: English

lines.value: he tried again but each time with the same results
lines.name: English

lines.value: he felt it was a landing gear problem that could have caused the aircraft to roll on its back if he had lifted the main gear off the ground
lines.name: English

lines.value: after looking at movies of the tests it was decided that the bouncing was probably caused by unwanted rudder movements
lines.name: English

lines.value: flight control system number two was replaced in favor of number one and it never bounced again
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was found that the car used to tow the aircraft was not powerful enough to entirely lift the m2-f1 off the ground so the frc arranged to have the tow car hot rodded by bill straub a conversion that tuned the engine for increased power added a rollbar and turned the front passenger seat to face aft so the passenger could observe the aircraft
lines.name: English

lines.value: this proved successful and tow tests continued
lines.name: English

lines.value: speeds on tow inched up to 110 mph which allowed thompson to climb to about 20 ft then glide for about 20 seconds after releasing the line
lines.name: English

lines.value: that was the most that could be expected during an auto tow
lines.name: English

lines.value: these initial tests produced enough flight data about the m2-f1 to proceed with flights behind a us navy c 47 tow plane at greater altitudes
lines.name: English

lines.value: a nasa c 47 was used for all of the air tows
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first was on august 16 1963
lines.name: English

lines.value: the m2-f1 had recently been equipped with an ejection seat and small rockets - referred to by the test team as instant l/d - in the tail to extend the landing flare for about 5 seconds if needed and thompson prepared for the flight with a few more tows behind the pontiac
lines.name: English

lines.value: forward visibility in the m2-f1 was very limited on tow requiring thompson to fly about 20 ft higher than the c 47 so he could see the plane through the nose window
lines.name: English

lines.value: towing speed was about 100 mph
lines.name: English

lines.value: the c 47 took the craft to an altitude of where free flights back to rogers dry lake began
lines.name: English

lines.value: pilot for the first series of flights of the m2-f1 was nasa research pilot milt thompson
lines.name: English

lines.value: typical glide flights with the m2-f1 lasted about two minutes and reached speeds of
lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.value: at above the ground the nose was lowered to increase speed to about 150 mph flare was at 200 ft from a 20° dive
lines.name: English

lines.value: the landing was smooth and the lifting body program was on its way
lines.name: English

lines.value: the m2-f1 was flown until august 16 1966
lines.name: English

lines.value: it proved the lifting body concept and led the way for subsequent metal heavyweight designs

lines.value: chuck yeager bruce peterson and don mallick also flew the m2-f1

lines.value: the success of dryden's m2-f1 program led to nasa's development and construction of two heavyweight lifting bodies based on studies at nasa's ames and langley research centers - the northrop m2-f2 and the northrop hl 10 both built by the northrop corporation and the us air force's x 24 program

lines.value: gender trouble feminism and the subversion of identity 1990 second edition 1999 is a book by the philosopher judith butler in which the author argues that gender is a kind of improvised performance
lines.name: English

lines.value: the work is influential in feminism women's studies and lesbian and gay studies and has also enjoyed widespread popularity outside of traditional academic circles
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler's ideas about gender came to be seen as foundational to queer theory and the advancing of dissident sexual practices during the 1990s
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler criticizes one of the central assumptions of feminist theory that there exists an identity and a subject that requires representation in politics and language
lines.name: English

lines.value: for butler women and woman are categories complicated by factors such as class ethnicity and sexuality
lines.name: English

lines.value: moreover the universality presumed by these terms parallels the assumed universality of the patriarchy and erases the particularity of oppression in distinct times and places
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler thus eschews identity politics in favor of a new coalitional feminism that critiques the basis of identity and gender
lines.name: English

lines.value: she challenges assumptions about the distinction often made between sex and gender according to which sex is biological while gender is culturally constructed
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler argues that this false distinction introduces a split into the supposedly unified subject of feminism
lines.name: English

lines.value: sexed bodies cannot signify without gender and the apparent existence of sex prior to discourse and cultural imposition is only an effect of the functioning of gender
lines.name: English

lines.value: sex and gender are both constructed
lines.name: English

lines.value: examining the work of the philosophers simone de beauvoir and luce irigaray butler explores the relationship between power and categories of sex and gender
lines.name: English

lines.value: for beauvoir women constitute a lack against which men establish their identity for irigaray this dialectic belongs to a signifying economy that excludes the representation of women altogether because it employs phallocentric language
lines.name: English

lines.value: both assume that there exists a female self identical being in need of representation and their arguments hide the impossibility of being a gender at all
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler argues instead that gender is performative no identity exists behind the acts that supposedly express gender and these acts constitute rather than express the illusion of the stable gender identity
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the appearance of being a gender is thus an effect of culturally influenced acts then there exists no solid universal gender constituted through the practice of performance the gender woman like the gender man remains contingent and open to interpretation and resignification in this way butler provides an opening for subversive action
lines.name: English

lines.value: she calls for people to trouble the categories of gender through performance
lines.name: English

lines.value: discussing the patriarchy butler notes that feminists have frequently made recourse to the supposed pre patriarchal state of culture as a model upon which to base a new non oppressive society
lines.name: English

lines.value: for this reason accounts of the original transformation of sex into gender by means of the incest taboo have proven particularly useful to feminists
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler revisits three of the most popular the anthropologist claude levi-strauss's anthropological structuralism in which the incest taboo necessitates a kinship structure governed by the exchange of women joan riviere's psychoanalytic description of womanliness as a masquerade that hides masculine identification and therefore also conceals a desire for another woman and sigmund freud's psychoanalytic explanation of mourning and melancholia in which loss prompts the ego to incorporate attributes of the lost loved one in which cathexis becomes identification
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler extends these accounts of gender identification in order to emphasize the productive or performative aspects of gender
lines.name: English

lines.value: with levi-strauss she suggests that incest is a pervasive cultural fantasy and that the presence of the taboo generates these desires with riviere she states that mimicry and masquerade form the essence of gender with freud she asserts that gender identification is a kind of melancholia in which the sex of the prohibited object is internalized as a prohibition 63 and therefore that same-sexed gender identification depends on an unresolved but simultaneously forgotten homosexual cathexis with the father not the mother of the oedipal myth
lines.name: English

lines.value: for butler heterosexual melancholy is culturally instituted as the price of stable gender identities 70 and for heterosexuality to remain stable it demands the notion of homosexuality which remains prohibited but necessarily within the bounds of culture
lines.name: English

lines.value: finally she points again to the productivity of the incest taboo a law which generates and regulates approved heterosexuality and subversive homosexuality neither of which exists before the law
lines.name: English

lines.value: in response to the work of the psychoanalyst jacques lacan that posited a paternal symbolic order and a repression of the feminine required for language and culture julia kristeva added women back into the narrative by claiming that poetic language the semiotic -was a surfacing of the maternal body in writing uncontrolled by the paternal logos
lines.name: English

lines.value: for kristeva poetic writing and maternity are the sole culturally permissible ways for women to return to the maternal body that bore them and female homosexuality is an impossibility a near psychosis
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler criticizes kristeva claiming that her insistence on a maternal that precedes culture and on poetry as a return to the maternal body is essentialist kristeva conceptualizes this maternal instinct as having an ontological status prior to the paternal law but she fails to consider the way in which that very law might well be the cause of the very desire it is said to repress 90
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler argues the notion of maternity as the long lost haven for females is a social construction and invokes foucault's arguments in the history of sexuality 1976 to posit that the notion that maternity precedes or defines women is itself a product of discourse
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler dismantles part of foucault's critical introduction to the journals he published of herculine barbin an intersex person who lived in france during the 19th century and eventually committed suicide when she was forced to live as a man by the authorities
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his introduction to the journals foucault writes of herculine's early days when she was able to live her gender or sex as she saw fit as a happy limbo of nonidentity 94
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler accuses foucault of romanticism claiming that his proclamation of a blissful identity prior to cultural inscription contradicts his work in the history of sexuality in which he posits that the idea of a real or true or originary sexual identity is an illusion in other words that sex is not the solution to the repressive system of power but part of that system itself
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler instead places barbin's early day not in a happy limbo but along a larger trajectory always part of a larger network of social control
lines.name: English

lines.value: she suggests finally that foucault's surprising deviation from his ideas on repression in the introduction might be a sort of confessional moment or vindication of foucault's own homosexuality of which he rarely spoke and on which he permitted himself only once to be interviewed
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler traces the feminist theorist monique wittig's thinking about lesbianism as the one recourse to the constructed notion of sex
lines.name: English

lines.value: the notion of sex is always coded as female according to wittig a way to designate the non male through an absence
lines.name: English

lines.value: women thus reduced to sex cannot escape carrying sex as a burden
lines.name: English

lines.value: wittig argues that even the naming of the body parts creates a fiction and constructs the features themselves fragmenting what was really once whole language repeated over time produces reality effects that are eventually misperceived as facts 115
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler questions the notion that the body itself is a natural entity that admits no genealogy a usual given without explanation how are the contours of the body clearly marked as the taken for granted ground or surface upon which gender signification are inscribed a mere facticity devoid of value prior to significance 129
lines.name: English

lines.value: building on the thinking of the anthropologist mary douglas outlined in her purity and danger 1966 butler claims that the boundaries of the body have been drawn to instate certain taboos about limits and possibilities of exchange
lines.name: English

lines.value: thus the hegemonic and homophobic press has read the pollution of the body that aids brings about as corresponding to the pollution of the homosexual's sexual activity in particular his crossing the forbidden bodily boundary of the perineum
lines.name: English

lines.value: in other words butler's claim is that the body is itself a consequence of taboos that render that body discrete by virtue of its stable boundaries 133
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler proposes the practice of drag as a way to destabilize the exteriority interiority binary finally to poke fun at the notion that there is an original gender and to demonstrate playfully to the audience through an exaggeration that all gender is in fact scripted rehearsed and performed
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler attempts to construct a feminism via the politics of jurido discursive power from which the gendered pronoun has been removed or not presumed to be a reasonable category
lines.name: English

lines.value: she claims that even the binary of subject object which forms the basic assumption for feminist practices we women must become subjects and not objects is a hegemonic and artificial division
lines.name: English

lines.value: the notion of a subject is for her formed through repetition through a practice of signification 144
lines.name: English

lines.value: butler offers parody for example the practice of drag as a way to destabilize and make apparent the invisible assumptions about gender identity and the inhabitability of such ontological locales 146 as gender
lines.name: English

lines.value: by redeploying those practices of identity and exposing as always failed the attempts to become one's gender she believes that a positive transformative politics can emerge
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a convict he was transported to western australia in 1851 becoming a prominent early pioneer of the town of northampton
lines.name: English

lines.value: little is known of his early life except that he was educated and that at some point he worked as a sick bay attendant in the royal navy
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1850s he was carrying on business as a merchant and drysalter in manchester trading as horrocks schaer and co and in london in partnership with gustav kober as gustav kober and co he was declared bankrupt on 21 march 1851 at manchester

lines.name: English

lines.value: the uk census of 31 march 1851 showed horrocks to be resident at london's newgate prison

lines.value: on 9 april 1851 he pleaded guilty at the old bailey in london to forging and uttering three bills of exchange totaling ₤1247/0/2 ₤1247.01 and was sentenced to fourteen years transportation
lines.name: English

lines.value: horrocks departed woolwich on 23 october 1851 and portland on 2 november 1851 on board the marion arriving at fremantle on 31 january 1852

lines.name: English

lines.value: he was granted a ticket of leave in june 1853
lines.name: English

lines.value: the scarcity of medical officers led him to apply for the post of medical attendant at the convict hiring depot at lynton seven miles from port gregory a position that he accepted at a reduced salary of £20 a year because of his limited qualifications

lines.value: he became the depot's unofficial medical superintendent and was referred to locally as dr horrocks

lines.value: he also against regulations treated and dispensed to the settlers of the area which eventually saw him reprimanded and in 1854 he resigned

lines.value: horrocks received a conditional pardon on 19 april 1856 and set up as a storekeeper and postmaster at wanerenooka northampton while continuing to provide for the community's medical needs free of charge

lines.value: the maunder minimum also known as the prolonged sunspot minimum is the name used for the period around 1645 to 1715 during which sunspots became exceedingly rare as was then noted by solar observers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the term was introduced after john a eddy published a landmark 1976 paper in science
lines.name: English

lines.value: astronomers before eddy had also named the period after the solar astronomers annie russell maunder 1868-1947 and her husband edward walter maunder 1851-1928 who studied how sunspot latitudes changed with time
lines.name: English

lines.value: the period which the spouses examined included the second half of the 17th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: two papers were published in edward maunder's name in 1890 and 1894 and he cited earlier papers written by gustav sporer
lines.name: English

lines.value: see like the dalton minimum and the sporer minimum the maunder minimum coincided with a period of lower than average european temperatures
lines.name: English

lines.value: the maunder minimum occurred between 1645 and 1715 when very few sunspots were observed
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was not due to a lack of observations during the 17th century giovanni domenico cassini carried out a systematic program of solar observations at the observatoire de paris thanks to the astronomers jean picard and philippe de la hire
lines.name: English

lines.value: johannes hevelius also performed observations on his own
lines.name: English

lines.value: the total numbers of sunspots but not wolf numbers in different years were as follows during the maunder minimum enough sunspots were sighted so that 11-year cycles could be extrapolated from the count
lines.name: English

lines.value: the maxima occurred in 1676 1677 1684 1695 1705 and 1718
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sunspot activity was then concentrated in the southern hemisphere of the sun except for the last cycle when the sunspots appeared in the northern hemisphere too
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to sporer's law at the start of a cycle spots appear at ever lower latitudes until they average at about latitude 15° at solar maximum
lines.name: English

lines.value: the average then continues to drift lower to about 7° and after that while spots of the old cycle fade new cycle spots start appearing again at high latitudes
lines.name: English

lines.value: the visibility of these spots is also affected by the velocity of the sun's surface rotation at various latitudes visibility is somewhat affected by observations being done from the ecliptic
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ecliptic is inclined 7° from the plane of the sun's equator latitude 0°
lines.name: English

lines.value: the maunder minimum roughly coincided with the middle part of the little ice age during which europe and north america experienced colder than average temperatures
lines.name: English

lines.value: whether there is a causal relationship however is still controversial
lines.name: English

lines.value: research at the technical university of denmark and the hebrew university of jerusalem has linked large solar eruptions to changes in the earth's cloud cover and clouds are known to affect global temperatures
lines.name: English

lines.value: the current best hypothesis for the cause of the little ice age is that it was the result of volcanic action
lines.name: English

lines.value: the onset of the little ice age also occurred well before the beginning of the maunder minimum
lines.name: English

lines.value: the correlation between low sunspot activity and cold winters in england has recently been analyzed using the longest existing surface temperature record the central england temperature record
lines.name: English

lines.value: they emphasize that this is a regional and seasonal effect relating to european winters and not a global effect
lines.name: English

lines.value: a potential explanation of this has been offered by observations by nasa's solar radiation and climate experiment which suggest that solar uv output is more variable over the course of the solar cycle than scientists had previously thought
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2011 an article was published in the nature geoscience journal that uses a climate model with stratospheric layers and the sorce data to tie low solar activity to jet stream behavior and mild winters in some places southern europe and canada/greenland and colder winters in others northern europe and the united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: in europe examples of very cold winters are 1683 84 1694 95 and the winter of 1708 09
lines.name: English

lines.value: the term little ice age applied to the maunder minimum is something of a misnomer as it implies a period of unremitting cold and on a global scale which was not the case
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example the coldest winter in the central england temperature record is 1683 1684 but the winter just two years later both in the middle of the maunder minimum was the fifth warmest in the whole 350-year cet record
lines.name: English

lines.value: also summers during the maunder minimum were not significantly different from those seen in subsequent years
lines.name: English

lines.value: the drop in global average temperatures in paleoclimate reconstructions at the start of the little ice age was between about 1560 and 1600 whereas the maunder minimum began almost 50 years later
lines.name: English

lines.value: past solar activity may be recorded by various proxies including carbon 14 and beryllium 10
lines.name: English

lines.value: these indicate lower solar activity during the maunder minimum
lines.name: English

lines.value: the scale of changes resulting in the production of carbon 14 in one cycle is small about one percent of medium abundance and can be taken into account when radiocarbon dating is used to determine the age of archaeological artifacts
lines.name: English

lines.value: the interpretation of the beryllium 10 and carbon 14 cosmogenic isotope abundance records stored in terrestrial reservoirs such as ice sheets and tree rings has been greatly aided by reconstructions of solar and heliospheric magnetic fields based on historic data on geomagnetic storm activity which bridge the time gap between the end of the usable cosmogenic isotope data and the start of modern spacecraft data
lines.name: English

lines.value: other historical sunspot minima have been detected either directly or by the analysis of the cosmogenic isotopes these include the sporer minimum 1450-1540 and less markedly the dalton minimum 1790-1820
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a 2012 study sunspot minima have been detected by analysis of carbon 14 in lake sediments
lines.name: English

lines.value: in total there seem to have been 18 periods of sunspot minima in the last 8000 years and studies indicate that the sun currently spends up to a quarter of its time in these minima
lines.name: English

lines.value: a paper based on an analysis of a flamsteed drawing suggests that the sun's surface rotation slowed in the deep maunder minimum 1684
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the maunder minimum aurorae had been observed seemingly normally with a regular decadal scale cycle
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is somewhat surprising because the later and less deep dalton sunspot minimum is clearly seen in auroral occurrence frequency at least at lower geomagnetic latitudes
lines.name: English

lines.value: because geomagnetic latitude is an important factor in auroral occurrence lower-latitude aurorae requiring higher levels of solar terrestrial activity it becomes important to allow for population migration and other factors that may have influenced the number of reliable auroral observers at a given magnetic latitude for the earlier dates
lines.name: English

lines.value: decadal scale cycles during the maunder minimum can also be seen in the abundances of the beryllium 10 cosmogenic isotope which unlike carbon 14 can be studied with annual resolution but these appear to be in antiphase with any remnant sunspot activity
lines.name: English

lines.value: an explanation in terms of solar cycles in loss of solar magnetic flux was proposed in 2012
lines.name: English

lines.value: the fundamental papers on the maunder minimum eddy legrand gleissberg schroder landsberg et al have been published in case studies on the sporer maunder and dalton minima
lines.name: English

lines.value: mission san juan bautista is a spanish mission in san juan bautista san benito county california
lines.name: English

lines.value: founded on june 24 1797 by fermin lasuen of the franciscan order the mission was the fifteenth of the spanish missions established in present day california
lines.name: English

lines.value: named for saint john the baptist the mission is the namesake of the city of san juan bautista
lines.name: English

lines.value: barracks for the soldiers a nunnery the jose castro house and other buildings were constructed around a large grassy plaza in front of the church and can be seen today in their original form
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ohlone the original residents of the valley were brought to live at the mission and baptized followed by yokuts from the central valley
lines.name: English

lines.value: mission san juan bautista has served mass daily since 1797 and today functions as a parish church of the diocese of monterey
lines.name: English

lines.value: following its creation in 1797 san juan's population grew quickly
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1803 there were 1036 native americans living at the mission
lines.name: English

lines.value: ranching and farming activity had moved apace with 1036 cattle 4600 sheep 22 swine 540 horses and 8 mules counted that year
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the same time the harvest of wheat barley and corn was estimated at 2018 fanegas each of about 220 pounds
lines.name: English

lines.value: father pedro estevan tapis who had a special talent for music joined father felipe arroyo de la cuesta at mission san juan bautista in 1815 to teach singing to the indians
lines.name: English

lines.value: he employed a system of notation developed in spain that uses varied colors or textures for polyphonic music usually from bottom to top solid black solid red black outline sometimes solid yellow and red outline or black outline when yellow was used
lines.name: English

lines.value: his choir of native american boys performed for many visitors earning the san juan bautista mission the nickname the mission of music two of his handwritten choir books are preserved at the san juan bautista museum
lines.name: English

lines.value: when father tapis died in 1825 he was buried on the mission grounds
lines.name: English

lines.value: the town of san juan bautista which grew up around the mission expanded rapidly during the california gold rush and continues to be a thriving community today
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mission is situated adjacent to the san andreas fault and has suffered damage from numerous earthquakes such as those of 1800 and 1906
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the mission was never entirely destroyed at once
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was restored initially in 1884 and then again in 1949 with funding from the hearst foundation
lines.name: English

lines.value: the three bell campanario or bell wall located by the church entrance was fully restored in 2010
lines.name: English

lines.value: an unpaved stretch of the original el camino real just east of the mission lies on a fault scarp
lines.name: English

lines.value: although initially secularized in 1835 the church was reconsecrated by the roman catholic church in 1859 and continues to serve as a parish of the diocese of monterey
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mission includes a cemetery with the remains of over 4000 native american converts and europeans buried there
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mission and its grounds were featured prominently in the 1958 alfred hitchcock film vertigo
lines.name: English

lines.value: associate producer herbert coleman's daughter judy lanini suggested the mission to hitchcock as a filming location
lines.name: English

lines.value: a steeple added sometime after the mission's original construction and secularization had been demolished following a fire so hitchcock added a bell tower using scale models matte paintings and trick photography at the paramount studio in los angeles
lines.name: English

lines.value: the tower does not resemble the original steeple
lines.name: English

lines.value: the tower's staircase was assembled inside a studio
